revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-22 11:18:39.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Always delegate OVS plug to os-vif

In change I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e, we started
delegating plugging of OVS ports to os-vif to work around a number of
bugs. However, this was only introduced for live migration. Plugging is
still handled by libvirt for spawn. This results in an odd situation,
whereby an interface of type 'bridge' will be use when creating the
instance initially, only for this to change to 'ethernet' on live
migration. Resolve this by *always* delegating plugging to os-vif. This
is achieved by consistently setting the 'delegate_create' attribute of
'nova.network.model.VIF' to 'True', which will later get transformed to
the 'create_port' attribute of the 'os_vif.objects.vif.VIFOpenVSwitch'
object(s) created in 'nova.network.os_vif_util._nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'
and ultimately result in delegate port creation.

Note that we don't need to worry about making the setting of
'delegate_create' conditional on whether we're looking at an OVS port or
not: this will be handled by '_nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'. We also don't
need to worry about unsetting this attribute before a live migration:
the 'delegate_create' attribute is always overridden as part of
'nova.objects.migrate_data.VIFMigrateData.get_dest_vif'.

Change-Id: I014c5a81752f86c6b99d19d769c42f318e18e676
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1734320
Related-Bug: #1815989
"}, {'created': '2021-06-22 15:35:39.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Always delegate OVS plug to os-vif

In change I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e, we started

whereby an interface of type 'bridge' will be use when creating the
instance initially, only for this to change to 'ethernet' on live
migration. Resolve this by *always* delegating plugging to os-vif. This
is achieved by consistently setting the 'delegate_create' attribute of
'nova.network.model.VIF' to 'True', which will later get transformed to
the 'create_port' attribute of the 'os_vif.objects.vif.VIFOpenVSwitch'
object(s) created in 'nova.network.os_vif_util._nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'
and ultimately result in delegate port creation.

Note that we don't need to worry about making the setting of
'delegate_create' conditional on whether we're looking at an OVS port or
not: this will be handled by '_nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'. We also don't
need to worry about unsetting this attribute before a live migration:
the 'delegate_create' attribute is always overridden as part of
'nova.objects.migrate_data.VIFMigrateData.get_dest_vif'.

Change-Id: I014c5a81752f86c6b99d19d769c42f318e18e676
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1734320
Related-Bug: #1815989
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Always delegate OVS plug to os-vif

In change I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e, we started
delegating plugging of OVS ports to os-vif to work around a number of
bugs. However, this was only introduced for live migration. Plugging is
still handled by libvirt for spawn. This results in an odd situation,
whereby an interface of type 'bridge' will be use when creating the
instance initially, only for this to change to 'ethernet' on live
migration. Resolve this by *always* delegating plugging to os-vif. This
is achieved by consistently setting the 'delegate_create' attribute of
'nova.network.model.VIF' to 'True', which will later get transformed to
the 'create_port' attribute of the 'os_vif.objects.vif.VIFOpenVSwitch'
object(s) created in 'nova.network.os_vif_util._nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'
and ultimately result in delegate port creation.

Note that we don't need to worry about making the setting of
'delegate_create' conditional on whether we're looking at an OVS port or
not: this will be handled by '_nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs'. We also don't
need to worry about unsetting this attribute before a live migration:
the 'delegate_create' attribute is always overridden as part of
'nova.objects.migrate_data.VIFMigrateData.get_dest_vif'.

Change-Id: I014c5a81752f86c6b99d19d769c42f318e18e676
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1734320
Related-Bug: #1815989

messages: [{'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2021-07-20 09:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-07-20 09:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14510, 'date': '2021-07-22 08:10:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-26 17:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-20 09:46:07.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096

commit_message:
Introduce daily bug stats chart

This commit introduces daily bug stats graphs. To do this, this commit
also introduces nvd3 js library for enabling to use lineWithFocusChart.
It is not same style chart of the main pages ones. Because
stackedAreaWithFocusChart is a little bit buggy. So it sometimes shows
wrong charts. And I also think lineWithFocusChart is better than the
stackedArea chart because it is simple enough to understand the trend.

Change-Id: Iacf22cddbd676d1447cfd9ae8ba1e7ce387720f6

commit_message:
Remove use of simplejson library

The simplejson library was not included in the setup requirements. Since
it is not actually needed - the default json library works fine - it
should just be removed.

Change-Id: I50c083344ea91e8a169a8b503c9418d71ec541e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-20 09:45:14.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096

commit_message:
Allow user to set sysctl_net_ipv4_tcp_retries2

This patch is adding configuration option to
manipulate with kernel option sysctl_net_ipv4_tcp_retries2.

More informations about kernel option in [1][2]
and RedHat suggestion [3] to set for DBs and HA.

[1]: https://pracucci.com/linux-tcp-rto-min-max-and-tcp-retries2.html
[2]: https://blog.cloudflare.com/when-tcp-sockets-refuse-to-die/
[3]: https://access.redhat.com/solutions/726753

Closes-Bug: #1917068
Change-Id: Ia0decbbfa4e33b1889b635f8bb1c9094567a2ce6
(cherry picked from commit 09d0409ed4a69f514355925754e832e752f817ca)

The required-projects adds ara to src/opendev.org/recordsansible/ara which is used later: https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/zuul.d/system-config-run.yaml#L100

I found out that I forgot to retire the stable/0.x branch so this still works for now.
It's available on github: https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/tree/stable/0.x but I don't maintain it anymore.

To keep the current approach would mean to add ara's github repo in the Zuul included projects (like ansible/ansible is) and then update the required-project with the new name -- or install from source by cloning the repository from github first (or install directly from pip with git+https://...?)

Do you have a preference ?

> 2) https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/src/branch/master/scripts/scripts-library.sh#L202
> 3) https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests/src/branch/master/test-ansible-env-prep.sh#L199

These weren't required-projects but scripts that provided support for leveraging Depends-On based on the path opendev.org/recordsansible/ara. I don't think we've used it that much. I've proposed patches to simplify the installation:
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/777696
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests/+/777697

> 4) https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/playbooks/zuul-stream/pre.yaml#L10-L11

This is used by zuul-stream-functional which is the parent to zuul-stream-functional-2.8 and 2.9.
It uses bindep to install these packages: https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/blob/stable/0.x/bindep.txt

To keep the current approach we could add a task that clones the repository before the bindep role is called and set the right path.

Would that work ?"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-06-01 00:26:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > 4) https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/playbooks/zuul-stream/pre.yaml#L10-L11
> 
> This is used by zuul-stream-functional which is the parent to zuul-stream-functional-2.8 and 2.9.
> It uses bindep to install these packages: https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/blob/stable/0.x/bindep.txt

The actual dependency seems to have been dropped with https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/631930 

I've proposed https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/793868 to clean this up

Although the zuul managed ansible does install a capped version; that's another problem though 😊"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-07-23 01:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2021-07-23 06:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2021-07-26 10:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2021-07-26 10:44:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Fixed the missing acl'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2021-07-26 10:45:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-07-26 16:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2021-07-26 17:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

[{'created': '2021-05-17 17:06:28.000000000', 'message': 'Reject open redirection in the console proxy

Our console proxies (novnc, serial, spice) run in a websockify server
whose request handler inherits from the python standard
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler. There is a known issue [1] in the
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler which allows open redirects by way of URLs
in the following format:

  http://vncproxy.my.domain.com//example.com/%2F..

which if visited, will redirect a user to example.com.

We can intercept a request and reject requests that pass a redirection
URL beginning with "//" by implementing the
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler.send_head() method containing the
vulnerability to reject such requests with a 400 Bad Request.

This code is copied from a patch suggested in one of the issue comments
[2].

Closes-Bug: #1927677

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue32084
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue32084#msg306545

Conflicts:
    nova/console/websocketproxy.py
    nova/tests/unit/console/test_websocketproxy.py

NOTE(melwitt): The conflicts are because the following changes are not
in Victoria:

  Ib2c406327fef2fb4868d8050fc476a7d17706e23 (Remove six.moves)
  I58b0382c86d4ef798572edb63d311e0e3e6937bb (Refactor and rename
    test_tcp_rst_no_compute_rpcapi)

Change-Id: Ie36401c782f023d1d5f2623732619105dc2cfa24
(cherry picked from commit 781612b33282ed298f742c85dab58a075c8b793e)
(cherry picked from commit 470925614223c8dd9b1233f54f5a96c02b2d4f70)
'}]
commit_message:
Reject open redirection in the console proxy

Our console proxies (novnc, serial, spice) run in a websockify server
whose request handler inherits from the python standard
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler. There is a known issue [1] in the
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler which allows open redirects by way of URLs
in the following format:

  http://vncproxy.my.domain.com//example.com/%2F..

which if visited, will redirect a user to example.com.

We can intercept a request and reject requests that pass a redirection
URL beginning with "//" by implementing the
SimpleHTTPRequestHandler.send_head() method containing the
vulnerability to reject such requests with a 400 Bad Request.

This code is copied from a patch suggested in one of the issue comments
[2].

Closes-Bug: #1927677

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue32084
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue32084#msg306545

Conflicts:
    nova/console/websocketproxy.py
    nova/tests/unit/console/test_websocketproxy.py

NOTE(melwitt): The conflicts are because the following changes are not
in Victoria:

  Ib2c406327fef2fb4868d8050fc476a7d17706e23 (Remove six.moves)
  I58b0382c86d4ef798572edb63d311e0e3e6937bb (Refactor and rename
    test_tcp_rst_no_compute_rpcapi)

Change-Id: Ie36401c782f023d1d5f2623732619105dc2cfa24
(cherry picked from commit 781612b33282ed298f742c85dab58a075c8b793e)
(cherry picked from commit 470925614223c8dd9b1233f54f5a96c02b2d4f70)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-20 04:35:25.000000000', 'message': 'Retaining permission of VNF package files

During the "vnf package upload" operation, permission of files\xa0
which were compressed and uploaded, incorrectly changes to 644.

This is because of the bug present in the python zipfile module.
So whenever python zipfile module is used for the extraction,\xa0
It changes the permission of the file to 644 incorrectly.

So this patch will resolve this issue and retain the permission of\xa0
those files which were compressed and uploaded.

Closes-Bug: #1923540
Change-Id: I71aad5f879e6df21f679187283957c59b73e0643

commit_message:
Retaining permission of VNF package files

Python zipfile module changes permission of the zip file
contents to 644 incorrectly while extracting zip file.

This is because of the bug present in the python zipfile module:
https://bugs.python.org/issue15795

This patch will resolve this issue and retain the permission of
files.

Co-Authored-By: Shanu Pandit <shanu.pandit@india.nec.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sheel Rana <ranasheel2000@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1923540
Change-Id: I71aad5f879e6df21f679187283957c59b73e0643

Do we need to make some changes for sphinx?'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-11 20:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"tox  -eapi-ref" always reports same error even without making any changes in tacker api-ref contents.

Cloning into 'tacker'...

api-ref develop-inst: /opt/stack/test_tacker/l/tacker
....
....
Extension error (os_api_ref):
Handler <function add_assets at 0x7f1339ea9790> for event 'builder-inited' threw an exception (exception: 'Sphinx' object has no attribute 'add_stylesheet')
ERROR: InvocationError for command /opt/stack/test_tacker/l/tacker/.tox/api-ref/bin/sphinx-build -W -b html -d api-ref/build/doctrees api-ref/source api-ref/build/html (exited with code 2)
__________________________________________________________________ summary ___________________________________________________________________
ERROR:   api-ref: commands failed
stack@rana:~/test_tacker/l/tacker$'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-12 03:15:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Exactly same issue on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/785303'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-12 09:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-12 16:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-14 10:47:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dear All,
 
Sharing details for reference purpose only.
 
Current api-ref build Issue on Zuul:
------------------------------------------------------
Extension error (os_api_ref):
Handler <function add_assets at 0x7f70841a0b80> for event 'builder-inited' threw an exception (exception: 'Sphinx' object has no attribute 'add_stylesheet')
ERROR: InvocationError for command /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/tacker/.tox/api-ref/bin/sphinx-build -W -b html -d api-ref/build/doctrees api-ref/source api-ref/build/html (exited with code 2)
------------------------------------------------------

It seems sphinx version on zuul is 4.0 (I am not sure about zuul configurations)
(https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/doc/requirements.txt)

add_stylesheet() is being used in sphinx (zuul) which has been deprecated in sphinxV1.8 and has been removed in sphinxV4.0
We need to replace "add_stylesheet()" to "add_css_file()" to eliminate ongoing zuul test failures for api-ref.
 
Reference:
https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ja/master/extdev/deprecated.html#dev-deprecated-apis
https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/7747'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-14 11:06:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Seems following os-api-ref patch may fix this issue:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-api-ref/+/765788'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-14 13:35:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-17 13:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2021-05-18 07:22:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Sheel,

This error might be because of some deprecated functions still used in os-api-ref library. I'm not sure which version the change was made, but it's happened in my tox environment using sphinx-build 4.0.1.

I've confirmed that this error can be avoided by changing the function calling in `.tox`.
tacker/.tox/api-ref/lib/python3.8/site-packages/os_api_ref/__init__.py
Need to change `add_stylesheet` to `add_css_file`, and `add_javascript` to `add_js_file`.

To pass the test on zuul, I think os_api_ref should be updated, or version of sphinx-build should be upper limited."}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2021-05-18 07:30:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

For your changes itself, I've also confirmed that it passes compilation of sphinx-build after updating the deprecated functions. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-18 07:49:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Hi Sheel,
> 
> This error might be because of some deprecated functions still used in os-api-ref library. I'm not sure which version the change was made, but it's happened in my tox environment using sphinx-build 4.0.1.
> 
> I've confirmed that this error can be avoided by changing the function calling in `.tox`.
> tacker/.tox/api-ref/lib/python3.8/site-packages/os_api_ref/__init__.py
> Need to change `add_stylesheet` to `add_css_file`, and `add_javascript` to `add_js_file`.
> 
> To pass the test on zuul, I think os_api_ref should be updated, or version of sphinx-build should be upper limited.

Mr Ogawa, 
Following patch is already merged one day ago and have updated these changes in os-api-ref https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-api-ref/+/765788/1/os_api_ref/__init__.py

It may take some more time to reflect these changes on zuul I guess.
Thank you!"}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2021-05-18 07:49:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
>

commit_message:
Incomplete URLs in api-ref

Host-path is missing in some of the api-ref
sample files.

This patch adds host-path in such related api-ref
sample files.

Change-Id: Iaee9daf266a6377b5de0d258aee6bcf9c6aef36e

commit_message:
Improvement of Processing Logic for Healing

The following patch will fix the issue wherein if VM name
and AutoScalingGroup name are the same name, unhealthy is
set for both and both are target for healing.

The fix will be in Instantiation part since the root cause
of the issue is that Nova::Server is not included as resource
in vnfcResourceInfo.

Closes-Bug: #1924214
Change-Id: I06849ebb068253e4691b5cfd03caac80bdc16cae

The path to the inventory file specified within the tox.ini
is invalid, as the file doesn't exist. Producing unnecessary warnings.

Furthemore, playbooks initiated during tox test runs
are targeting localhost explicitly.

Closes-Bug: #1937367

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Removing inventory file path from tox

The path to the inventory file specified within the tox.ini
is invalid, as the file doesn't exist. Producing unnecessary warnings.

Furthemore, playbooks initiated during tox test runs
are targeting localhost explicitly.

Closes-Bug: #1937367

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I204c6ee27fb9f4c7324d90b86fd8835fab473375

   a. ceph-ansible v4.0.62 (promoted) [2]

   c. ceph-ansible logs [4]

2. scenario004:
   a. ceph-ansible v4.0.62 (promoted) [5]
   b. container: daemon:v4.0.19-stable-nautilus [6]
   c. ceph-ansible logs [7]
   d. tempest run with TestObjectStorageBasicOps.test_swift_acl_anonymous_download [8]


Note that since [1] Depends-on the revert [9], the tempest test that previously failed is now working.

commit_message:
Bump nautilus containers to v4.0.19

This change solves multiple issues present with the 4.0.13 containers,
especially with RGW and the related tempest tests.
The purpose of this review is moving from v4.0.13 to v4.0.19 tag, which
has the latest released content.

Change-Id: I8cbba356867145a0076c5426f4ac7642195ea357

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 04:06:37.000000000', 'message': "Update User Guide

The current Tacker User Guide is not well organized.  There are many use
cases listed and it's not clear that whether it is for Legacy Tacker or
ETSI NFV-SOL Tacker, what resources and operations are related.  Also,
there are some unnecessary documents.

Reorganized the User Guide page according to the proposal in
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tacker-wallaby-revise-docs.

- Classified Legacy Tacker documents and ETSI NFV documents.
- Classified the use cases by resources, operations, and VM or
Container.
- Removed the following documents which seem to be no longer necessary:
  - Tacker conductor [1]
  - Deploying OpenWRT as VNF [2]

Reasons for deletion:
- Tacker conductor: It doesn't contain meaningful information for the
current Tacker 5.1.0dev34.
- Deploying OpenWRT as VNF: It doesn't work anymore. Since this document
is a guide for Legacy Tacker, we don't have to make an effort to modify
it.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/doc/source/contributor/tacker_conductor.rst
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/doc/source/install/deploy_openwrt.rst

Signed-off-by: Hiromu Asahina <hiromu.asahina.az@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: I97840667df5862e29b6d016dcfccd6bb28f4b669

commit_message:
Update User Guide

Reorganized the User Guide page according to the proposal in
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tacker-wallaby-revise-docs.

- Classified Legacy Tacker documents and ETSI NFV documents.
- Classified the use cases by resources, operations, and VM or
Container.
- Removed the following documents which seem to be no longer necessary:
 - Tacker conductor [1]
 - Deploying OpenWRT as VNF [2]
- Fixed the consistency of heading capitalization

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/doc/source/contributor/tacker_conductor.rst
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/src/branch/master/doc/source/install/deploy_openwrt.rst

Signed-off-by: Hiromu Asahina <hiromu.asahina.az@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: I97840667df5862e29b6d016dcfccd6bb28f4b669

commit_message:
MgmtDriver with Kubernetes cluster management OSS

This spec proposes Ansible interface for MgmtDriver to manage Kubernetes
cluster VNF.
As sample implementation, Tacker provides kubespray as Ansible playbooks
in MgmtDriver to install and configure Kubernetes cluster VNF.
Also, Load Balancer to expose CNF on the Kubernetes cluster VNF will be
supported.

Implements: blueprint k8s-mgmtdriver-kubespray
Change-Id: I5505afabf73ae06bf0f4bd14cd2b64b54b193575

commit_message:
Update references to sys.version_info

We support Python 3.6 as a minimum now.
Updating minimum version check from py2.6 to py3.6 and
removing no op checks.

Change-Id: Iac35026682578c30d06b29969e133438be777ebd

commit_message:
Fix exit code with bogus command name

Running this:

$ kolla-ansible bogus-command

Should show usage & give a non-zero exit code. Previously it gave a zero
exit code. This change fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1929397

Change-Id: I580c208d61d5efe115f936dfb8f3f6508acd91b2
(cherry picked from commit 86ddc94ec2f6ec46d6dfc4feeb58c12aaabcd252)

commit_message:
Disable docker's ip-forward when iptables disabled

With the new default since Wallaby, starting Docker makes it
enable forwarding and not filter it at all.
This may pose a security risk and should be mitigated.

Closes-Bug: #1931615
Change-Id: I5129136c066489fdfaa4d93741c22e5010b7e89d
(cherry picked from commit 0fa4ee56eb86eb7d4b4e3bb9d9c9993f6906c1bd)

[{'created': '2021-03-18 09:30:02.000000000', 'message': '[docker] Added a new flag to disable default network

Docker is using 172.17.0.0/16 by default for bridge networking on
docker0, and this might cause routing problems for operator networks.

This change introduces docker_disable_default_network to disable the
bridge networking by putting "bridge: none"[1] to daemon.json

Bridge networking does not work without iptables, so we set the default
for docker_disable_default_network to
docker_disable_default_iptables_rules.

For better defaults, this feature will be enabled by default in
Wallaby.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/dockerd/

commit_message:
[docker] Added a new flag to disable default network

Docker is using 172.17.0.0/16 by default for bridge networking on
docker0, and this might cause routing problems for operator networks.

This change introduces docker_disable_default_network to disable the
bridge networking by putting "bridge: none"[1] to daemon.json

Bridge networking does not work without iptables, so we set the default
for docker_disable_default_network to
docker_disable_default_iptables_rules.

For better defaults, this feature will be enabled by default in
Wallaby.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/dockerd/

Change-Id: Ic745300b27e50132d80d03787fa4abfada2d0173
Closes-Bug: #1848249
Related-Bug: #1849275
(cherry picked from commit 4053a0afdb3d0a230557883453b89b06cf4d7057)

commit_message:
[docker] Added a new flag to disable default network

Docker is using 172.17.0.0/16 by default for bridge networking on
docker0, and this might cause routing problems for operator networks.

This change introduces docker_disable_default_network to disable the
bridge networking by putting "bridge: none"[1] to daemon.json

Bridge networking does not work without iptables, so we set the default
for docker_disable_default_network to
docker_disable_default_iptables_rules.

For better defaults, this feature will be enabled by default in
Wallaby.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/dockerd/

Change-Id: Ic745300b27e50132d80d03787fa4abfada2d0173
Closes-Bug: #1848249
Related-Bug: #1849275
(cherry picked from commit 4053a0afdb3d0a230557883453b89b06cf4d7057)

commit_message:
Disable docker's ip-forward when iptables disabled

With the new default since Wallaby, starting Docker makes it
enable forwarding and not filter it at all.
This may pose a security risk and should be mitigated.

Closes-Bug: #1931615
Change-Id: I5129136c066489fdfaa4d93741c22e5010b7e89d
(cherry picked from commit 0fa4ee56eb86eb7d4b4e3bb9d9c9993f6906c1bd)

commit_message:
Allow user to set sysctl_net_ipv4_tcp_retries2

This patch is adding configuration option to
manipulate with kernel option sysctl_net_ipv4_tcp_retries2.

More informations about kernel option in [1][2]
and RedHat suggestion [3] to set for DBs and HA.

[1]: https://pracucci.com/linux-tcp-rto-min-max-and-tcp-retries2.html
[2]: https://blog.cloudflare.com/when-tcp-sockets-refuse-to-die/
[3]: https://access.redhat.com/solutions/726753

Closes-Bug: #1917068
Change-Id: Ia0decbbfa4e33b1889b635f8bb1c9094567a2ce6
(cherry picked from commit 09d0409ed4a69f514355925754e832e752f817ca)

commit_message:
Add base policy check module

This adds new v2/policy module which includes abstract kind of base
class which can be subclassed as per need to enforce policies for
different glance resources.

Related blueprint policy-refactor
Change-Id: I3cc6bab69af001ad0a2c3cf274c0f327953eec95

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-26 15:34:54.000000000', 'message': 'Improve support for configuring time sync services

Centos 8 ships with the Chrony time sync service enabled by default. This
service runs directly on the host. If someone enables the containerised Chrony
service, then you end up with two time sync services. A similar problem may
occur on Debian distros. Furthermore, if you enable the host NTP service, it
will try and enable ntpd on Centos8 which has now switched to Chrony. This
patch fixes those issues.

A further patch can support configuration of the Chrony service on the host,
for customising the NTP servers, for example.

Partial-Bug: #1885689
Change-Id: Iff8d377c3137b34a2e53aa5c0a26df8cae30a2e1
'}, {'created': '2020-11-26 15:38:55.000000000', 'message': 'Improve support for configuring time sync services

Centos 8 ships with the Chrony time sync service enabled by default.
This service runs directly on the host. If someone enables the
containerised Chrony service, then you end up with two time sync
services. A similar problem may occur on Debian distros. Furthermore,
if you enable the host NTP service, it will try and enable ntpd on
Centos8 which has now switched to Chrony. This patch fixes those
issues.

A further patch can support configuration of the Chrony service on
the host, for customising the NTP servers, for example.

Partial-Bug: #1885689
Change-Id: Iff8d377c3137b34a2e53aa5c0a26df8cae30a2e1
'}, {'created': '2020-11-27 17:28:29.000000000', 'message': 'Improve support for configuring time sync services

Centos 8 ships with the Chrony time sync service enabled by default.
This service runs directly on the host. If you enable the host
NTP service, it will try and enable ntpd on Centos8 which has now
switched to Chrony. This patch fixes those issues.

A further patch can support configuration of the Chrony service on
the host, for customising the NTP servers, for example.

An issue can also occur where if the Chrony container is disabled,
and then later enabled, both the host and container Chrony service
run at the same time, unless you specifically run the baremetal
role again. Since the container may be removed, this bug is not
addressed in this patch.

Partial-Bug: #1885689
Change-Id: Iff8d377c3137b34a2e53aa5c0a26df8cae30a2e1
'}]
commit_message:
Improve support for configuring time sync services

Centos 8 ships with the Chrony time sync service enabled by default.
This service runs directly on the host. If you enable the host
NTP service, it will try and enable ntpd on Centos8 which has now
switched to Chrony. This patch fixes those issues.

A further patch can support configuration of the Chrony service on
the host, for customising the NTP servers, for example.

An issue can also occur where if the Chrony container is disabled,
and then later enabled, both the host and container Chrony service
run at the same time, unless you specifically run the baremetal
role again. Since the container may be removed, this bug is not
addressed in this patch.

Partial-Bug: #1885689
Change-Id: Iff8d377c3137b34a2e53aa5c0a26df8cae30a2e1

subject: Allow Ironic to act as a power control intermediary
messages:
[{'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2020-11-30 17:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2020-11-30 17:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10342, 'date': '2020-12-04 21:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

This specification is missing a significant amount of detail required for this implementation. In addition, I think this is conflating two features: first, the addition of get/set endpoints to the Ironic API for power state and boot device; secondly, the creation of a redfish emulator that acts as a client.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2020-12-07 01:42:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> (4 comments)
> 
> This specification is missing a significant amount of detail required for this implementation. In addition, I think this is conflating two features: first, the addition of get/set endpoints to the Ironic API for power state and boot device; secondly, the creation of a redfish emulator that acts as a client.

Hi! Thanks for the review; you raise some good points, and after playing with sushy-tools a bit more, I think there may be a simpler solution I can propose that excludes the need to make any changes in Ironic at all. One point of clarification: Ironic already has the get/set endpoints for power state/boot device.'}, {'account_id': 10342, 'date': '2020-12-07 15:29:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Looks like based on https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/ that there is an API for get/set boot device, and for set power state -- but not directly for get power state. It's likely you'd want to implement that here, with an option to ensure the data is live."}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2021-03-10 19:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2021-03-10 19:47:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@JayF I've uploaded a revised version of the spec that I believe removes the need for there to be any changes in Ironic at all. It's possible I'm confused, however; you mentioned in your previous review that the proposed changes would require adding new Ironic API endpoints. Wouldn't I be able to just call existing Ironic APIs... ?"}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-04-26 14:16:38.000000000', 'content': 'Hashtag added: ironic-week-prio'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-04-26 14:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So interesting possibility has been raised on Standalone context, allowing one ironic to chain to another ironic. This has come up before in discussion, would it make sense to have a specific call/meeting to discuss this sort of functionality.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2021-04-26 16:49:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> So interesting possibility has been raised on Standalone context, allowing one ironic to chain to another ironic. This has come up before in discussion, would it make sense to have a specific call/meeting to discuss this sort of functionality.

I admit I don't fully understand the purpose of chaining Ironics, but I'd definitely be interested in finding out!"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-28 12:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think this goes the wrong direction.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2021-04-28 14:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-29 07:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2021-04-29 13:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-07-26 15:24:57.000000000', 'content': 'Hashtag removed: ironic-week-prio'}]

commit_message:
Allow Ironic to act as a power control intermediary

This spec describes a new Ironic driver for sushy-tools that,
in conjunction to a small change in Ironic, allows Ironic to
act as a power control intermediary.

Change-Id: I7744a0fd2e8981a3a09c9963db30831026c73533
Task: 41334
Story: 2008401

subject: add tex-gyre package for tgtermes.sty
messages:
[{'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-07-26 11:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-07-26 14:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-07-26 14:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-07-26 14:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Per discussion in #openstack-infra, the latest Sphinx release is causing the openstack-tox-docs job to fail for some projects with "! LaTeX Error: File `tgtermes.sty' not found." https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e58c187bc90f43c8a2bb189a54c6175d/log/sphinx-build-pdf.log'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2021-07-26 15:00:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-07-26 15:06:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=tex-gyre also confirms this package is available on Ubuntu 18.04 and 20.04, while spot-checking on random old servers indicates it's been available with that name at least as far back as 14.04 and likely longer, so this should be entirely safe (at worst a no-op and slight increase in job runtime for additional package installs)."}]

commit_message:
add tex-gyre package for tgtermes.sty

This change fixes the pdf-docs job by installing
tex-gyre to provide the missing tgtermes.sty style.

Change-Id: I885ed9153d9ccd9d3a486b5fc573238520474592

commit_message:
Fix exit code with bogus command name

Running this:

$ kolla-ansible bogus-command

Should show usage & give a non-zero exit code. Previously it gave a zero
exit code. This change fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1929397

Change-Id: I580c208d61d5efe115f936dfb8f3f6508acd91b2
(cherry picked from commit 86ddc94ec2f6ec46d6dfc4feeb58c12aaabcd252)

commit_message:
Fix exit code with bogus command name

Running this:

$ kolla-ansible bogus-command

Should show usage & give a non-zero exit code. Previously it gave a zero
exit code. This change fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1929397

Change-Id: I580c208d61d5efe115f936dfb8f3f6508acd91b2
(cherry picked from commit 86ddc94ec2f6ec46d6dfc4feeb58c12aaabcd252)

commit_message:
Use single task for image upload for all releases

Follow up to patch 800965.
Use operator for all releases on image upload.
Remove tripleo_overcloud_image_upload_local to avoid
train failure.

subject: Revert "Deprecate support for networking-mlnx"
messages:
[{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-07-21 06:28:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-07-21 06:31:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

I reached out to Moshe and he confirmed we will continue maintaining the repo.
I'll put WIP for a while until the following concerns with current networking-mlnx are addressed.
---
1. stable/wallaby branch is not created

2. The repo still used openstack-python3-victoria-jobs-neutron job template which is for victoria
    The wallaby version should be used.

3. This is related to 2 but Python 3.8 should be tested and supported because that is included
    in tested runtime for wallaby
    https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html
---"}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-07-21 07:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2021-07-21 07:21:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Revert "Deprecate support for networking-mlnx"

This reverts commit faec067d3798836ca971a8324b582a1926e8f609.

Reason for revert:
It was confirmed that the plugin will be still maintained. Releases
for Victoria and Wallaby were created an job templates were updated to
be consistent with branches in neutron repos.

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-22 16:15:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fix incorrect handling/update about deprecated parameters

This is a follow-up of 3864e15998b5b1eec7d2b1b4911add9bb899fdb8 and
fixes the following point.

- ipxe_enabled parameter was deprecated during Xena cycle. The logic
  to purge the parameter was added to remove the parameter during
  update and should be kept during Xena.

- We should not pass undef directly to *_config resource because it
  results in an empty value in configuration files. We should replace
  the value by $::os_service_default to remove that parameter.

Change-Id: I02aadb4501c124e3373fe0d98453fc755ec82500
'}, {'created': '2021-07-22 16:17:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix incorrect handling/update about deprecated parameters

This is a follow-up of 3864e15998b5b1eec7d2b1b4911add9bb899fdb8 and
fixes the following point.

- ipxe_enabled parameter was deprecated during Xena cycle. The logic
  to purge the parameter was added to remove the parameter during
  update and should be kept during Xena.

- We should not pass undef directly to *_config resource because it
  results in an empty value in configuration files. We should replace
  the value by $::os_service_default to remove that parameter.

- It is recommended to gather deprecated parameters in one place
  in parameter definition block.

Change-Id: I02aadb4501c124e3373fe0d98453fc755ec82500
'}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect handling/update about deprecated parameters

This is a follow-up of 3864e15998b5b1eec7d2b1b4911add9bb899fdb8 and
fixes the following point.

- ipxe_enabled parameter was deprecated during Xena cycle. The logic
  to purge the parameter was added to remove the parameter during
  update and should be kept during Xena.

- We should not pass undef directly to *_config resource because it
  results in an empty value in configuration files. We should replace
  the value by $::os_service_default to remove that parameter.

- It is recommended to gather deprecated parameters in one place
  in parameter definition block.

Change-Id: I02aadb4501c124e3373fe0d98453fc755ec82500

subject: Allow to symlink barbican_user_libraries
messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-22 15:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 31542, 'date': '2021-07-23 13:48:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-07-26 12:20:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-22 15:19:35.000000000', 'message': "Allow to symlink barbican_user_libraries

When barbican uses PKCS#11 crypt plugin, libCryptoki2 library tends to
search for Chrystoki.conf inside /etc by default. At the same time it's
tricky to place file there at once since approriate permissions not
always could be set for files that reside directly in /etc.
As a workaround to this Chrystoki.conf can be placed inside /opt and
symlinked to /etc to satisfy library.

Change-Id: I6267d3b65f514c4ad4cb5494f111463e685b6fbb
(cherry picked from commit 05c5ab38e430654ea5093960e995ef5fc79e784c)
"}]
commit_message:
Allow to symlink barbican_user_libraries

When barbican uses PKCS#11 crypt plugin, libCryptoki2 library tends to
search for Chrystoki.conf inside /etc by default. At the same time it's
tricky to place file there at once since approriate permissions not
always could be set for files that reside directly in /etc.
As a workaround to this Chrystoki.conf can be placed inside /opt and
symlinked to /etc to satisfy library.

Change-Id: I6267d3b65f514c4ad4cb5494f111463e685b6fbb
(cherry picked from commit 05c5ab38e430654ea5093960e995ef5fc79e784c)

subject: Bump default tox env from py37 to py38
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-24 15:33:46.000000000', 'message': 'Bump default tox env from py37 to py38

Python 3.8 is now our highest level supported python runtime.
This updates the default tox target environments to swap out
py37 for py38 to make sure local development testing is
covering this version.

This does not impact zuul jobs in any way, nor prevent local
tests against py37. It just changes the default if none is
explicitly provided.

Change-Id: I3f7095ee84d3df88e2815ab830c1b670cb322d58
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Bump default tox env from py37 to py38

Python 3.8 is now our highest level supported python runtime.
This updates the default tox target environments to swap out
py37 for py38 to make sure local development testing is
covering this version.

This does not impact zuul jobs in any way, nor prevent local
tests against py37. It just changes the default if none is
explicitly provided.

Change-Id: I3f7095ee84d3df88e2815ab830c1b670cb322d58
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of mock

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we can use the
standard lib unittest.mock module instead.

Change-Id: Ida175bb1e9f871d18dd5b746d8c108f824604315
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-10-13 16:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-10-13 16:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-10-21 12:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-12-04 19:26:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-12-07 14:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1 Review-Priority+1

Hi Sean,

Thanks for addressing these. My only concern is the migration script changes we have always been very keen to not change unless we absolutely have to. Mainly for not alerting people that something might have been wrong with them and that they would need to address issues in old migrations.

I was looking the patches merged in hacking and I could not find what is actually causing those #noqa tags to fail. Is there a way we could exclude the glance/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo as whole instead of changing the scripts? (We really should never have reason to touch those files anyways.)

If changing the #noqa tags around is really our only option we should add a note of that in the release notes indicating why those scripts has changed and that the change does not affect any deployments.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-07-26 13:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Change-Id: Iacaddd9ae6a9af3d34b5e58d604badb01360fae7
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Address new hacking enforcement issues

New rule enforcement has been enabled in the latest hacking code. To
avoid breakage later when these changes are released, this addresses a
few of the issues that the newer code will error on.

Change-Id: Iacaddd9ae6a9af3d34b5e58d604badb01360fae7
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Replace deprecated inspect.getargspec

inspect.getargspec was deprecated since Python 3.0 and
inspect.getfullargspec is its replacement with correct handling of
function annotations and keyword-only parameters[1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.getargspec

Change-Id: I1d72d3879a8aa12fdbe722f7b2370b44b9fd71e7

subject: Use skipTest() instead of skip() method
messages: [{'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2021-07-03 02:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2021-07-12 23:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 31857, 'date': '2021-07-13 06:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1\n\nLGTM.'}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2021-07-13 06:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 16237, 'date': '2021-07-14 13:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17255, 'date': '2021-07-26 11:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-03 02:43:21.000000000', 'message': 'Use skipTest() instead of skip() method

The method for skipping a test in unittest is skipTest().
testtools also provides skip(), but that is deprecated.

This patch eliminates the deprecation warnings by switching
to the recommended skipTest().

commit_message:
Use skipTest() instead of skip() method

The method for skipping a test in unittest is skipTest().
testtools also provides skip(), but that is deprecated.

This patch eliminates the deprecation warnings by switching
to the recommended skipTest().

Change-Id: Ic7ab96edbe6a5312aa50edb6fccb38004e8158fb

commit_message:
Zuul FT environment change to use OVN

The devstack patch [1] that set default ML2 driver from OVS to OVN
has been merged.

[1] Change default network backend driver to ML2/OVN
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/791436

This patch change to set ML2 driver to OVN in zuul environment for FT.

Change-Id: I2ab70503e09a96e80378e4676e377037042d8c42

[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-07-26 08:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-07-26 11:08:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded. For checking Nova with Ceph, add a comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Ceph Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/802239/1/iscsi : SUCCESS in 2h 30m 15s'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-26 08:35:04.000000000', 'message': "api: Align availability zone info with forced host

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original and
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone requested matches that of the host (or, more
specifically, the host is a member of the host aggregates that form the
availability zone [1]). If not, simply ignore the requested availability
zone information in favour of using the availability zone of the host,
logging a warning just for record keeping purposes. This is deemed
preferable to failing with HTTP 400 (Bad Request) since what users are
really requesting by using this was to schedule to a specific host: the
availability zone portion of the request is really irrelevant and just
an artifact of this legacy mechanism to request hosts. If users wish to
truly validate a host-availability zone combo, they can use the 'host'
field introduced in microversion 2.74 along with the 'availability_zone'
field:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az --host host ...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1934770
(cherry picked from commit 8f21ee42bd66b62e75e14acf4e91b786d78b9168)
(cherry picked from commit 58782403cdaad33856fd59715525cee3c63ee3cf)
(cherry picked from commit bf235c0ed0a1a867ab1b6e5ff34eaf7a8dee6c55)
"}]
commit_message:
api: Align availability zone info with forced host

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original and
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone requested matches that of the host (or, more
specifically, the host is a member of the host aggregates that form the
availability zone [1]). If not, simply ignore the requested availability
zone information in favour of using the availability zone of the host,
logging a warning just for record keeping purposes. This is deemed
preferable to failing with HTTP 400 (Bad Request) since what users are
really requesting by using this was to schedule to a specific host: the
availability zone portion of the request is really irrelevant and just
an artifact of this legacy mechanism to request hosts. If users wish to
truly validate a host-availability zone combo, they can use the 'host'
field introduced in microversion 2.74 along with the 'availability_zone'
field:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az --host host ...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1934770
(cherry picked from commit 8f21ee42bd66b62e75e14acf4e91b786d78b9168)

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no

create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability

more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live

possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

subject: Fix error that cannot overwrite policy rule for 'forced_host'
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-26 08:37:17.000000000', 'message': "Fix error that cannot overwrite policy rule for 'forced_host'

When configure 'os_compute_api:servers:create:forced_host' to
'rule:admin_or_owner', but still doesn't allow.
In nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L669, the target is
set to '{}' that is not equal None, so then it will not be set
in nova/policy.py#L205.
This patch configures the target param.

Change-Id: I7a563386bd2f5d1930b5eb2cfc00425a19747e24
Closes-Bug: #1894975
(cherry picked from commit fd99a7ca0f56223d878142a58525d9ed64c84ed1)
(cherry picked from commit 35ec9357a1f249cc1309c92006a5a1f48a8ff025)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error that cannot overwrite policy rule for 'forced_host'

When configure 'os_compute_api:servers:create:forced_host' to
'rule:admin_or_owner', but still doesn't allow.
In nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L669, the target is
set to '{}' that is not equal None, so then it will not be set
in nova/policy.py#L205.
This patch configures the target param.

Change-Id: I7a563386bd2f5d1930b5eb2cfc00425a19747e24
Closes-Bug: #1894975
(cherry picked from commit fd99a7ca0f56223d878142a58525d9ed64c84ed1)
(cherry picked from commit 35ec9357a1f249cc1309c92006a5a1f48a8ff025)

commit_message:
Change documentation for devstack deployment.

Reflect reality to the docs regarding devstack deployment.
Also, there were changes to refresh docs for vagrant, updated
Vagrantfile, and removed outdated Opendaylight docs.

Change-Id: Ic038967547ebf748c5b41ad598e8553c4a6bebad

commit_message:
nova_virtlogd_wrapper: Simplify string matching

Currently the nova_virtlogd_wrapper script has some lower/upper case
patterns to match strings to identify container status, but this
requires redundant but careful definitions.

This change "lowercase"s status string so that we can define status
more simply.

Change-Id: Ia3f9679b7a43d3ab7315b5d87b31c87ba9c14109

subject: Fix grep for /dev/disk/by-id to identify SCSI devices
messages: [{'account_id': 31832, 'date': '2021-07-24 19:09:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2021-07-26 09:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nThis is a duplicate of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/753312'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-24 19:09:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix grep for /dev/disk/by-id to identify SCSI devices

For VMs with hw_disk_bus=scsi and/or hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi
the volume won't be identified, because for those VMs the result
from `ls /dev/disk/by-id` will look like this:

scsi-0QEMU_QEMU_HARDDISK_3c8f086d-e1f4-4ce1-a91a-c4a8d6d538bb

This patch extends the current grep by allowing the full UUID of
the volume to be matched as well.

Change-Id: I3c6b7a85f8cbf5a8379965c44be854ea3002123b
"}]
commit_message:
Fix grep for /dev/disk/by-id to identify SCSI devices

For VMs with hw_disk_bus=scsi and/or hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi
the volume won't be identified, because for those VMs the result
from `ls /dev/disk/by-id` will look like this:

scsi-0QEMU_QEMU_HARDDISK_3c8f086d-e1f4-4ce1-a91a-c4a8d6d538bb

This patch extends the current grep by allowing the full UUID of
the volume to be matched as well.

Change-Id: I3c6b7a85f8cbf5a8379965c44be854ea3002123b

This currently runs in the 'check' pipeline, as part of the pep8 job,

commit_message:
Move 'check-cherry-picks' test to gate, n-v check

This currently runs in the 'check' pipeline, as part of the pep8 job,
which causes otherwise perfectly valid backports to report as failing
CI. There's no reason a stable core shouldn't be encouraged to review
these patches: we simply want to prevent them *merging* before their
parent(s). Resolve this conflict by moving the check to separate voting
job in the 'gate' pipeline as well as a non-voting job in the 'check'
pipeline to catch more obvious issues.

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflict as I91b8056e73658fc815eb2f6711e89d4ab5deed92
isn't present on stable/wallaby.

Conflicts:
  .zuul.yaml

Change-Id: Id3e4452883f6a3cf44ff58b39ded82e882e28c23
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 98b01c9a59df4912f5a162c2c52d1f00c84d24c2)

[{'created': '2021-05-20 13:51:15.000000000', 'message': 'Support memory fragmentation tuning

In some high memory pressure scenarios, the memory shortage would make
the high order pages hard to be allocated and also the page allocation
would go to the synchronous frequently reclaim thanks to the default gap
between min<->low<->high is too small to wake up the kswapd(asynchronous
reclaim) earlier. The spec proposes a mechanism to fine-tune the sysctl
memory parameters(min_free_kbytes/watermark_scale_factor) at runtime to
improve the situation.

commit_message:
Support memory fragmentation tuning

In some high memory pressure scenarios, the memory shortage would make
the high order pages hard to be allocated and also the page allocation
would go to the synchronous frequently reclaim thanks to the default gap
between min<->low<->high is too small to wake up the kswapd(asynchronous
reclaim) earlier. The spec proposes a mechanism to fine-tune the sysctl
memory parameters(min_free_kbytes/watermark_scale_factor) at runtime to
improve the situation.

Change-Id: Ifbbca53b28e8e5f470eba9b64abeda27c74b61f1

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-09 12:44:24.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp ONTAP: Fix QoS lost after moving volume

When a Cinder volume is created with a volume-type associated to a QoS
entity, the driver creates a QoS policy group at the ONTAP back end, and
associates it to the entity representing the Cinder volume (either a LUN
or a file within an NFS share).

On NetApp NFS, when a migrate operation is issued and it completes, the
resulting volume ends up without a QoS.  That happens because the file
is being renamed while the QoS refers to the now non-existent file.

This patch makes it so that the file is not renamed when finishing a
migration and the driver code uses the ``name_id`` attribute instead of
the ``id`` one to refer to the right UUID.

Closes-Bug: #1906291
Change-Id: Icd7a929e7cbce0c74f6b340f4e09f74a8098d752
(cherry picked from commit da100e1fca610cefb7e77079ab3170b068e328a2)
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix QoS lost after moving volume

When a Cinder volume is created with a volume-type associated to a QoS
entity, the driver creates a QoS policy group at the ONTAP back end, and
associates it to the entity representing the Cinder volume (either a LUN
or a file within an NFS share).

On NetApp NFS, when a migrate operation is issued and it completes, the
resulting volume ends up without a QoS.  That happens because the file
is being renamed while the QoS refers to the now non-existent file.

This patch makes it so that the file is not renamed when finishing a
migration and the driver code uses the ``name_id`` attribute instead of
the ``id`` one to refer to the right UUID.

Closes-Bug: #1906291
Change-Id: Icd7a929e7cbce0c74f6b340f4e09f74a8098d752
(cherry picked from commit da100e1fca610cefb7e77079ab3170b068e328a2)

commit_message:
Fix exit code with bogus command name

Running this:

$ kolla-ansible bogus-command

Should show usage & give a non-zero exit code. Previously it gave a zero
exit code. This change fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1929397

Change-Id: I580c208d61d5efe115f936dfb8f3f6508acd91b2

please update the commit message with answers to the linked questions (looks ok though, but would be nice to know what happens if you don't want to maintain autopage anymore).

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#for-new-requirements"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2021-07-06 20:16:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2021-07-06 20:30:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> would be nice to know what happens if you don't want to maintain autopage anymore).

Fair question, it's a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem. If it is in use somewhere then maybe someone will be interested, but somebody has to go first.

I don't expect keeping it working with new Python releases (as opposed to adding new features) to be very much work, if any, and I have (work) time available to do it, so I am comfortable accepting the responsibility of being a sole maintainer for now."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2021-07-13 02:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2021-07-26 03:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

ok'}]

autopage is a library for automatically invoking 'less' when needed in
command-line programs and piping the output through it. It is wanted to
improve the user experience of python-openstackclient and other
cliff-based command line tools.

The library is actively maintained (by me), and licensed under the
Apache 2.0 license. Distro packages for Fedora/CentOS and Ubuntu are
available in Copr and PPA, respectively:

https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/zaneb/autopage/packages/
https://launchpad.net/~zaneb/+archive/ubuntu/autopage

Change-Id: Ic773519e5ab3e940cb23a96b99295f7eb8986691
"}, {'created': '2021-07-06 20:16:57.000000000', 'message': "Add autopage to global-requirements

autopage is a library for automatically invoking 'less' when needed in
command-line programs and piping the output through it. It is wanted to
improve the user experience of python-openstackclient and other
cliff-based command line tools.

Review questions:
* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes (by me).

* Is the library good code?

I wrote it, so I'd like to think so. I've been testing it out in one of
my own projects in a lot of different scenarios, and I believe it has
got to the point where it is very robust.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes (requires Python 3.6 or later).

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes, Apache 2.0 license.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

No, but the necessary packaging files are available upstream, and distro
packages for Fedora/CentOS and Ubuntu are available in Copr and PPA,
respectively:

https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/zaneb/autopage/packages/
https://launchpad.net/~zaneb/+archive/ubuntu/autopage

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

Not that I know of.

* Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, of course.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cliff/+/799344
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cliff/+/799345

* If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
  does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

N/A

* Do I need to update anything else?

No, there are no transitive dependencies.

Change-Id: Ic773519e5ab3e940cb23a96b99295f7eb8986691
"}, {'created': '2021-07-13 02:20:39.000000000', 'message': "Add autopage to global-requirements

No, but the necessary packaging files are available upstream, and distro

https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/zaneb/autopage/packages/
https://launchpad.net/~zaneb/+archive/ubuntu/autopage

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in

commit_message:
Add autopage to global-requirements

autopage is a library for automatically invoking 'less' when needed in
command-line programs and piping the output through it. It is wanted to
improve the user experience of python-openstackclient and other
cliff-based command line tools.

Review questions:
* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes (by me).

* Is the library good code?

I wrote it, so I'd like to think so. I've been testing it out in one of
my own projects in a lot of different scenarios, and I believe it has
got to the point where it is very robust.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes (requires Python 3.6 or later).

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes, Apache 2.0 license.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

No, but the necessary packaging files are available upstream, and distro
packages for Fedora/CentOS and Ubuntu are available in Copr and PPA,
respectively:

https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/zaneb/autopage/packages/
https://launchpad.net/~zaneb/+archive/ubuntu/autopage

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

Not that I know of.

* Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, of course.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cliff/+/799344
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cliff/+/799345

* If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
  does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

N/A

* Do I need to update anything else?

No, there are no transitive dependencies.

Change-Id: Ic773519e5ab3e940cb23a96b99295f7eb8986691

Is there a reason this needs to be a library, there seems to be a bunch of things you can do natively in python for datetime ranges?  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/993358/creating-a-range-of-dates-in-python  I will say the library does seem cleaner, just don't want to turn this into nodejs :P"}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2021-07-06 11:11:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> Is there a reason this needs to be a library, there seems to be a bunch of things you can do natively in python for datetime ranges?  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/993358/creating-a-range-of-dates-in-python  I will say the library does seem cleaner, just don't want to turn this into nodejs :P

I read the same stackoverflow and other places. Also the same question that a friend posed. Well, if we write the code, it is more to maintain, document, and to guarantee that it works (via unit testings normally). By adopting a library, I know that there is a solid solution, tested, and used out there. Moreover, it is less code to maintain throughout time.

I personally see no reason to replicate others work. So, if there is already a code (library) that does exactly what I need, it is well maintained, the code is neat, documented, I do not see the rationality not to adopt it.

If people are opposed to adopting it, I would rewrite it, or part of the solution in CloudKitty. However, I do not see that as the best approach, specially in the opensource world."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2021-07-26 03:35:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

Add datetimerange library to global requirements

While developing a new feature in CloudKitty, we adopt a library
(datetimerange) to facilitate the handling/processing of
datetime ranges. Therefore, to make the Zuul requirements check
happy, we are introducing this new dependency into the global
requirements file.

Here follows the answers to the new library requirement questions:

1 - Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, it is. As we see in [1], the component has more or less one
yearly release. It is a very focused library, so this release process
makes sense.

2 - Is the library good code?

Yes, it is. As we can see in [2], it has a 95% of code coverage.
Moreover, while navigating in the code repository, we can see that
methods are well documented, and coded.

3 - Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, it is. That is also found in the README of the project in [2].

4 - Is the library license compatible?

According to reference [3]:

```
In order to be acceptable as dependencies of OpenStack projects,
external libraries (produced and published by 3rd-party developers)
must be licensed under an OSI-approved license that does not restrict
distribution of the consuming project. The list of acceptable licenses
includes ASLv2, BSD (both forms), MIT, PSF, LGPL, ISC, and MPL.
Licenses considered incompatible with this requirement include GPLv2,
GPLv3, and AGPL.
```

Therefore, the project fits nicely into these requirements. The project
in question is licensed under MIT, as we can see in [2], in the right
corner part of the page, and also in the LICENSE file at the root of
the project.

5 - Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

It is installed via PIP; PIP is available in major distros. Therefore,
it is possible to use this library in all of them by issues the command
`pip install DateTimeRange`.

6 - Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
in global-requirements.txt?

No. At least, I did not find it.

7 - Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, it is. We have a new feature being developed ion Cloudkitty in
[4], which needs this library to handle DateTime ranges.

[1] https://github.com/thombashi/DateTimeRange/releases
[2] https://github.com/thombashi/DateTimeRange
[3] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/licensing.html
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cloudkitty/+/799207

8 - If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

It is not managed by the OpenStack release process.

9 - Do I need to update anything else?

No.

Change-Id: I608331e28ef349399068f9b1fa16bd6a6c5779e6
'}, {'created': '2021-07-05 13:30:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add datetimerange library to global requirements

commit_message:
Add datetimerange library to global requirements

While developing a new feature in CloudKitty, we adopt a library
(datetimerange) to facilitate the handling/processing of
datetime ranges. Therefore, to make the Zuul requirements check
happy, we are introducing this new dependency into the global
requirements file.

Add datetimerange library to global requirements

While developing a new feature in CloudKitty, we adopt a library
(datetimerange) to facilitate the handling/processing of
datetime ranges. Therefore, to make the Zuul requirements check
happy, we are introducing this new dependency into the global
requirements file.

Here follows the answers to the new library requirement questions:

1 - Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, it is. As we see in [1], the component has more or less one
yearly release. It is a very focused library, so this release process
makes sense.

2 - Is the library good code?

Yes, it is. As we can see in [2], it has a 95% of code coverage.
Moreover, while navigating in the code repository, we can see that
methods are well documented, and coded.

3 - Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, it is. That is also found in the README of the project in [2].

4 - Is the library license compatible?

According to reference [3]:

```
In order to be acceptable as dependencies of OpenStack projects,
external libraries (produced and published by 3rd-party developers)
must be licensed under an OSI-approved license that does not restrict
distribution of the consuming project. The list of acceptable licenses
includes ASLv2, BSD (both forms), MIT, PSF, LGPL, ISC, and MPL.
Licenses considered incompatible with this requirement include GPLv2,
GPLv3, and AGPL.
```

Therefore, the project fits nicely into these requirements. The project
in question is licensed under MIT, as we can see in [2], in the right
corner part of the page, and also in the LICENSE file at the root of
the project.

5 - Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

It is installed via PIP; PIP is available in major distros. Therefore,
it is possible to use this library in all of them by issues the command
`pip install DateTimeRange`.

6 - Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
in global-requirements.txt?

No. At least, I did not find it.

7 - Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, it is. We have a new feature being developed ion Cloudkitty in
[4], which needs this library to handle DateTime ranges.

8 - If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process
does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

It is not managed by the OpenStack release process.

9 - Do I need to update anything else?

No.

[1] https://github.com/thombashi/DateTimeRange/releases
[2] https://github.com/thombashi/DateTimeRange
[3] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/licensing.html
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cloudkitty/+/799207
