subject: Role parameter for tripleo_kernel_defer_reboot
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 17216, 'name': 'Martin Schuppert', 'email': 'mschuppert@redhat.com', 'username': 'mcschupp'}, {'_account_id': 18575, 'name': 'Saravanan KR', 'email': 'krsacme@gmail.com', 'username': 'saravanankr'}, {'_account_id': 20733, 'name': 'Rajesh Tailor', 'email': 'ratailor@redhat.com', 'username': 'rajesht'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-20 17:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-20 17:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-07-20 21:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2021-07-21 06:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2021-07-21 08:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2021-07-21 08:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Is this really required to expose? It is not exposed as it should be used with care. Since we already support changing kernel args on update, I prefer we dont expose this parameter. Open to discussion, if we see a need, then I am OK with it.

>>>>>>

The ansible parameter in discussion "tripleo_kernel_defer_reboot" is
supported, but it is not exposed as THT parameter as it will have
side-effects. For example, after the update is complete if this
parameter is not removed, then even scale-out operation will also use
the parameter and will not reboot new nodes, which may result in
failure. User has to ensure after the update, the parameter is removed
so that any further cluster operations are not affected.'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-21 13:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> Is this really required to expose? It is not exposed as it should be used with care. Since we already support changing kernel args on update, I prefer we dont expose this parameter. Open to discussion, if we see a need, then I am OK with it.
> 
> >>>>>>
> 
> The ansible parameter in discussion "tripleo_kernel_defer_reboot" is
> supported, but it is not exposed as THT parameter as it will have
> side-effects. For example, after the update is complete if this
> parameter is not removed, then even scale-out operation will also use
> the parameter and will not reboot new nodes, which may result in
> failure. User has to ensure after the update, the parameter is removed
> so that any further cluster operations are not affected.

We've seen operators complaining about unexpected reboots of their computes with workload during stack updates, either because of human error on their side, or because of 3rd parties.

While we don't recommend to enable this switch, this can be easily applied anyways with ExtraGroupVars, which is, at best, a hacky way of achieving this. Having this as a parameter will simply ensure that the safety measure is documented and available.

The problem with unexpected reboots is the impact on workload, this is the worse kind of outage for operators because they couldn't proactively failover, their customers might be impacted, and this gives a bad reputation to the product to upper management, even if it's not necessarily our fault.

I think it's less impacting for operators to forget to disable this then having their nodes with workload getting rebooted. Failure in scale-out is normally impact-less to their customers.

I can certainly describe the impacts of leaving this enabled in the description.'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-21 13:20:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-21 13:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2021-07-21 13:36:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> We've seen operators complaining about unexpected reboots of their computes with workload during stack updates, either because of human error on their side, or because of 3rd parties.

This unexpected reboots could be because of kernel arg changes, which has been handled in the patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/775216

With this there should not be any reboot on an existing node. Do you think any other cases that could cause reboot?"}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-21 13:46:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > We've seen operators complaining about unexpected reboots of their computes with workload during stack updates, either because of human error on their side, or because of 3rd parties.
> 
> This unexpected reboots could be because of kernel arg changes, which has been handled in the patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/775216
> 
> With this there should not be any reboot on an existing node. Do you think any other cases that could cause reboot?

I've seen 3rd parties making changes to their templates during updates that caused a reboot and I've seen human errors on the operator's side as well. We can discuss this offline if you want to see the actual case."}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-21 16:29:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > We've seen operators complaining about unexpected reboots of their computes with workload during stack updates, either because of human error on their side, or because of 3rd parties.
> 
> This unexpected reboots could be because of kernel arg changes, which has been handled in the patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/775216
> 
> With this there should not be any reboot on an existing node. Do you think any other cases that could cause reboot?

One last thing about this patch. It works if we modify kernelargs after a deployment with kernelargs defined. If a node was scaled up with no kernelargs and we add some kernelargs, this patch will not prevent the node from getting rebooted, even the node is probably running some workload as seen here: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975240"}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2021-07-22 04:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> One last thing about this patch. It works if we modify kernelargs after a deployment with kernelargs defined. If a node was scaled up with no kernelargs and we add some kernelargs, this patch will not prevent the node from getting rebooted, even the node is probably running some workload as seen here: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975240

IIUC, as upgrades require mandatory kernel arg for tsx, the nodes will have kernel args added with TSX=on. OK, I can understand the need to expose it. I am OK with the patch (will update once zuul clears).

Have you considered handling tsx reboot case within the tripleo_kernel role iself? Instead of asking users to add the flag and remove it later, the special condition can be added in reboot checks itself.'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:34:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:35:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > One last thing about this patch. It works if we modify kernelargs after a deployment with kernelargs defined. If a node was scaled up with no kernelargs and we add some kernelargs, this patch will not prevent the node from getting rebooted, even the node is probably running some workload as seen here: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975240
> 
> IIUC, as upgrades require mandatory kernel arg for tsx, the nodes will have kernel args added with TSX=on. OK, I can understand the need to expose it. I am OK with the patch (will update once zuul clears).
> 
> Have you considered handling tsx reboot case within the tripleo_kernel role iself? Instead of asking users to add the flag and remove it later, the special condition can be added in reboot checks itself.

Yes, we tried but it was refused [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/783969'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-07-22 20:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2021-07-23 03:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-23 16:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2021-07-24 14:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Role parameter for tripleo_kernel_defer_reboot

To help operators protect their workload, they can now enable the
KernelArgsDeferReboot role parameter. This will prevent the tripleo-kernel
ansible module from automatically rebooting nodes even if KernelArgs
were changed unexpectedly.

Change-Id: I52e43f264a03775b6d609444f8da1a36d9565281

commit_message:
feat: Add make build

1. Add dockerfile
2. Modify gunicorn config

1. Move skyline-apiserver to libs
2. Modify Makefile
3. Rename the skyline-apiserver.yaml.sample file to skyline.yaml.sample

At the top level, we use "skyline" to manage the project like a monorepo, including 
some common configuration files (mypy.ini, black.conf, isort.conf, etc.).

In the `libs` directory, there are three core libraries, skyline-console, skyline-apiserver, 
skyline-nginx, and some dependent libraries. 
There are cross-imports between these libraries, for example: skyline-nginx requires 
skyline-apiserver; Both skyline-nginx and skyline-apiserver require skyline-config. 
Therefore, skyline-apiserver should not be placed at the top level, it is also suitable for 
management as a library.

commit_message:
refactor: Move skyline-apiserver to libs

1. Move skyline-apiserver to libs
2. Modify Makefile
3. Rename the skyline-apiserver.yaml.sample file to skyline.yaml.sample

At the top level, we use "skyline" as the namespace, using the idea of
monorepo to manage the project. At the top level, only some common
configuration files (mypy.ini, black.conf, isort.conf, etc.) and
common tools are included.

In the `libs` directory, there are three core libraries,
skyline-console, skyline-apiserver, skyline-nginx, and some dependent
libraries.
There are cross-imports between these libraries,
for example: skyline-nginx requires skyline-apiserver;
Both skyline-nginx and skyline-apiserver require skyline-config.

Therefore, skyline-apiserver should not be placed
at the top level, it is also suitable for management as a library.


Change-Id: Ie2f1f4bdfbc2e985ec4327705eecaae3181f5b50

commit_message:
[Rocky and before] Drop octavia v1 job

Since Octavia EOLed its stable/stein and older branches, there is no
longer octavia v1 job defined. Because the job has been non-voting
let's remove the job to resolve job definition error.

This change also caps bandit to v1.6.2 because bandit 1.6.3[1] release
has dropped support for Python 2[2].

[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/releases/tag/1.6.3
[2] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/615

Change-Id: If1b493707bd012d4a779dc6deba1a70ac3293ec6

commit_message:
Migrate from testr to stestr

* Replace .testr.conf by .stestr.conf for migration and update
  .gitignore and test-requirements.txt file accordingly
* Use py3 as the default runtime for tox
* Add a new job, openstack-cover-jobs, to run the coverage in Zuul
* Use tox version 3.18.0 for using allowlist_externals

Signed-off-by: JyotiJauhari <jyotijauhari222@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifd6fc7b0c22919b91fff9eb136de8c023bce3849

commit_message:
[Stable-only] Pin Gnocchi to a specific release

Currently we use the latest Gnocchi in functional tests but this
often results problems caused by any update in Gnocchi side.
This change pins Gnocchi to a specific version to avoid such problems.

Backport note:
Because stable/train and older supports Python 2, Gnocchi 4.3.z is used
instead of Gnocchi 4.4.z which no longer supports Python 2.

Change-Id: I791f214c6c130973fff9703a0ada1efd93720ae6
(cherry picked from commit 6026253883fac20cffdd22f6d5feb4ca0800c806)
(cherry picked from commit 564a2ca6dfac2552c4537a9d99dffe167f074ec7)
(cherry picked from commit 9812f4b35a77fd17ddf158a96d13dcfbacea6152)
(cherry picked from commit 20756c9bd8ccb5e25c61e68769d04d4913725128)

commit_message:
[Stable-only] Pin Gnocchi to a specific release

Currently we use the latest Gnocchi in functional tests but this
often results problems caused by any update in Gnocchi side.
This change pins Gnocchi to a specific version to avoid such problems.

Backport note:
Because stable/train and older supports Python 2, Gnocchi 4.3.z is used
instead of Gnocchi 4.4.z which no longer supports Python 2.

Conflicts:
	devstack/settings

Change-Id: I791f214c6c130973fff9703a0ada1efd93720ae6
(cherry picked from commit 6026253883fac20cffdd22f6d5feb4ca0800c806)
(cherry picked from commit 564a2ca6dfac2552c4537a9d99dffe167f074ec7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-25 18:02:44.000000000', 'message': "WIP: api: Validate host belongs to availability zone

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original,
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone exists and the host is part of it (or, more
specifically, a member of the host aggregates that form the availability
zone [1]). If neither are true, fail with HTTP 400 (Bad Request). This
should not require an API microversion since users should not have to
opt into non-broken behavior.

WIP because I drafted this on a Friday evening and want to sanity check
the idea before I spend more time on this. We _surely_ have a fix for
this somewhere. fwiw, the exact command being used was
'--availability-zone nova:<host>' so it was using the default AZ. Not
sure if that matters.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2021-06-28 16:32:04.000000000', 'message': "WIP: api: Validate host belongs to availability zone

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original,
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone exists and the host is part of it (or, more
specifically, a member of the host aggregates that form the availability
zone [1]). If neither are true, fail with HTTP 400 (Bad Request). This
should not require an API microversion since users should not have to
opt into non-broken behavior.

WIP because I drafted this on a Friday evening and want to sanity check
the idea before I spend more time on this. We _surely_ have a fix for
this somewhere. fwiw, the exact command being used was
'--availability-zone nova:<host>' so it was using the default AZ. Not
sure if that matters.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2021-07-06 12:16:49.000000000', 'message': "api: Align availability zone info with forced host

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original and
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone requested matches that of the host (or, more
specifically, the host is a member of the host aggregates that form the
availability zone [1]). If not, simply ignore the requested availability
zone information in favour of using the availability zone of the host,
logging a warning just for record keeping purposes. This is deemed
preferable to failing with HTTP 400 (Bad Request) since what users are
really requesting by using this was to schedule to a specific host: the
availability zone portion of the request is really irrelevant and just
an artifact of this legacy mechanism to request hosts. If users wish to
truly validate a host-availability zone combo, they can use the 'host'
field introduced in microversion 2.74 along with the 'availability_zone'
field:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az --host host ...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1934770
"}, {'created': '2021-07-06 13:40:23.000000000', 'message': "api: Align availability zone info with forced host

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original and
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone requested matches that of the host (or, more
specifically, the host is a member of the host aggregates that form the
availability zone [1]). If not, simply ignore the requested availability
zone information in favour of using the availability zone of the host,
logging a warning just for record keeping purposes. This is deemed
preferable to failing with HTTP 400 (Bad Request) since what users are
really requesting by using this was to schedule to a specific host: the
availability zone portion of the request is really irrelevant and just
an artifact of this legacy mechanism to request hosts. If users wish to
truly validate a host-availability zone combo, they can use the 'host'
field introduced in microversion 2.74 along with the 'availability_zone'
field:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az --host host ...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1934770
"}]
commit_message:
api: Align availability zone info with forced host

Users can create a server like so:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az:host ...

This is a historical way to request that an instance be scheduled to a
specific host and it causes the scheduler to be bypassed. However, no
validation of this availability zone-host combo takes place. The host
could in fact belong to a different availability zone. If it does, we'll
end up in a very odd situation whereby the RequestSpec record for the
instance will record the availability zone requested by the user at
create time, but the Instance record itself will record the availability
zone of the host on which the instance was scheduled. This leads to even
more confusing behavior when we attempt to do something like live
migrate the instance since the RequestSpec record, with its original and
possibly invalid availability zone information, is used. The
'AvailabilityZoneFilter' will fail an error message like the following:

  Availability Zone 'foo' requested. ... has AZs: bar

but the 'openstack server list --long' command will show a non-foo value
for the availability zone column.

The solution is simple: when given an availability zone-host combo, make
sure the availability zone requested matches that of the host (or, more
specifically, the host is a member of the host aggregates that form the
availability zone [1]). If not, simply ignore the requested availability
zone information in favour of using the availability zone of the host,
logging a warning just for record keeping purposes. This is deemed
preferable to failing with HTTP 400 (Bad Request) since what users are
really requesting by using this was to schedule to a specific host: the
availability zone portion of the request is really irrelevant and just
an artifact of this legacy mechanism to request hosts. If users wish to
truly validate a host-availability zone combo, they can use the 'host'
field introduced in microversion 2.74 along with the 'availability_zone'
field:

  $ openstack server create --availability-zone az --host host ...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/aggregates.html

Change-Id: Iac0e634e66cd4e150a50935cf635f626fc11b70e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1934770

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-18 17:15:51.000000000', 'message': "objects: Fix VIFMigrateData.supports_os_vif_delegation setter

We're using a 'profile' getter/setter in the 'VIFMigrateData' object to
ensure we transform the JSON encoded string we store in the database to
an actual dictionary on load and vice versa on save. However, because
the getter is returning a new object (constructed from 'json.loads')
rather than a reference to the original data (which is a string),
modifying this object doesn't actually change the underlying data in the
object. We were relying on this broken behavior to set the
'supports_os_vif_delegation' attribute of the 'VIFMigrateData' object
and trigger the delegated port creation introduced in change
I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e, which means that code isn't
actually doing anything yet. Resolve this.

Change-Id: I362deb1088c88cdcd8219922da9dc9a01b10a940
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1734320
Related-Bug: #1815989
"}]
commit_message:
objects: Fix VIFMigrateData.supports_os_vif_delegation setter

We're using a 'profile' getter/setter in the 'VIFMigrateData' object to
ensure we transform the JSON encoded string we store in the database to
an actual dictionary on load and vice versa on save. However, because
the getter is returning a new object (constructed from 'json.loads')
rather than a reference to the original data (which is a string),
modifying this object doesn't actually change the underlying data in the
object. We were relying on this broken behavior to set the
'supports_os_vif_delegation' attribute of the 'VIFMigrateData' object
and trigger the delegated port creation introduced in change
I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e, which means that code isn't
actually doing anything yet. Resolve this.

Change-Id: I362deb1088c88cdcd8219922da9dc9a01b10a940
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1734320
Related-Bug: #1815989

[{'created': '2021-07-24 10:56:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fast fix ceph-ansible bootstrap issue

ceph-ansible used to merge a lot of PR in small periods of time
which results in OSA bootstrap breakage.
Until more proper solution lands, we fast-fix that with increase of role
clone depth.

Change-Id: I3bf9f5c77f2881d875d982b3ea0e8b9fbc0c0c23
'}]
commit_message:
Fast fix ceph-ansible bootstrap issue

ceph-ansible used to merge a lot of PR in small periods of time
which results in OSA bootstrap breakage.
Until more proper solution lands, we fast-fix that with increase of role
clone depth.

Change-Id: I3bf9f5c77f2881d875d982b3ea0e8b9fbc0c0c23

What is it still missing for this to be not WIP? Unit test and release notes?'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2021-06-29 13:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In addition to the question above, I need to ask the same question I've written down in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/786260 : "should we be able to observe any effect of this patch on the higher level testing, like in the cinder-plugin-ceph-tempest job? I think that job works even without this patch, so maybe some test there is missing? (but if it is, it can be addressed outside this patch, I'm just curious)."'}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:37:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This change is ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

A release note is coming.  Is it appropriate to add a unit test that

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> What is it still missing for this to be not WIP? Unit test and release notes?'}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, with the right configuration this should be observable.  The job
works because glance images are not in raw format and require
translation, which causes the clone() logic to be skipped.

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> In addition to the question above, I need to ask the same question I've written down in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/786260 : "should we be able to observe any effect of this patch on the higher level testing, like in the cinder-plugin-ceph-tempest job? I think that job works even without this patch, so maybe some test there is missing? (but if it is, it can be addressed outside this patch, I'm just curious)."'}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-22 13:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ahh, good catch, thanks.  I'll include that in the coming update.

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> I know this is a WIP, but I like this patch. Even though is a minimal change, as this affects consistency this patch may need a release note but I'm not sure[1]. Need to update unit test [2]
> 
> [1] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html
> [2] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py#L178"}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-22 14:14:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think your fix on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/786260 makes this unnecessary?  On the other hand, if cinder and glance are in sync, operators won't be seeing something that looks anomalous on the backend.  But, we can't control whether glance and cinder are actually using the same option values.  I have a more general question, though, namely what's the relation between chunk size and stripe width?  They seem to be conceptually different.  Has the chunk size option been hijacked into something it's not really appropriate for?

I also have Luigi's question about why we aren't seeing this in upstream CI.  (Maybe we're not using Pacific, though I thought we were.)

So a bunch of questions and no helpful suggestions, other than that changing the default value of a config option does require a release note."}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-24 21:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> I think your fix on
> https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/786260 makes this
> unnecessary?

No, my initial thinking was that Glance had increased their object size
from Ceph's default for a good reason due to average image size and
performance analysis.  However, I cannot find the reasoning for Glance's
change, it is included in a larger patch that doesn't address the object
size increase.

  https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/71ea2e9afd
  https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/213660d8b5

If we increase our default object size to match Glance's for cloned
volumes, the Pacific issue goes away - for the case where the defaults
are not changed.  That bug would of course come back if an admin
increased Glance's object size further without reflecting that change in
Cinder.  The goal with this patch is not to directly address the Pacific
bug, rather to bring Cinder in sync with Glance and possibly improve
performance in the default case.

Increasing object size isn't guaranteed to improve performance, it
really depends on I/O patterns.  Additionally, larger objects in RADOS
may impact recovery performance within the Ceph cluster itself.  I
suspect that performance analysis will show that a volume needs to be
significantly larger than a typical Glance image to see meaningful
performance increases from a larger object size.  What I'm trying to say
is that Ceph's default object size is also aligned with how Ceph does
recovery and internal data transfer and therefore we should have a good
and stated reason for deviating from the default.

Now that I've had a chance to consider it, I'm inclined to abandon this
patch and submit a Glance patch to return to the default value in the
absence of supporting evidence of performance improvements.

The other patch is definitely needed, as it handles the case where the
incoming value of object size from Glance is incompatible with that of
Cinder.  But this patch proposes a change as a result of noticing a
change elsewhere and for which there is no stated reasoning - and that
has a good chance of being wrong-headed I feel.

> On the other hand, if cinder and glance are in sync, operators won't
> be seeing something that looks anomalous on the backend.

True.

> But, we can't control whether glance and cinder are actually
> using the same option values.

Also true, but I address this in the above statement.

> I have a more general question, though, namely what's the relation
> between chunk size and stripe width?  They seem to be conceptually
> different.  Has the chunk size option been hijacked into something
> it's not really appropriate for?

They are conceptutally different, yes.  No hijacking is taking place,
here's what's up:

An RBD image is stripped over a set of objects, and these objects are
stored in RADOS, the distributed object store.  The result, among other
benefits, is that I/O to an RBD image is distributed across many nodes
within the Ceph cluster.  Because the client communicates directly with
the OSD nodes containing the desired data, no single node becomes a
bottleneck under high load.

There are three parameters that control RBD image stripping:

1. The size of the objects.  This must be a power of 2, defaults to 4MB,
and is the core of the bug this patch relates to.  It is the 'order'
parameter you see in the create() and clone() functions.  This is
caluculated from 'rbd_chunk_size' in our RBD driver in Cinder.

2. Strip unit, a set of contiquious bytes in a single object.  Once the
stripe unit is reached, we move to the next object.  This defaults to
the size of the object.  The cinder driver does not expose this.

3. Stripe count, after the stripe unit of bytes is written to an object
we return to the previous object until its maximum size is reached.
Once this happens, we move the next object.  This defaults to 1.  The
cinder driver does not expose this.

> I also have Luigi's question about why we aren't seeing this in
> upstream CI.  (Maybe we're not using Pacific, though I thought we
> were.)

Our CI doesn't store images in RAW format, rather QCOW2.  As a result,
Cinder must convert a glance image to RAW prior to importing it to a
volume and this process causes the clone() operation (and it's
performance benefits) to be unavailable, the clone function is never
called, and the bug is never seen.

> So a bunch of questions and no helpful suggestions, other than that
> changing the default value of a config option does require a release
> note."}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2021-07-24 21:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

See my last review response.'}]

commit_message:
[stable only] Fix NeutronL3AgentAvailabilityZone parameter

The config setting had two checks in same item so the part about
NeutronL3AgentAvailabilityZone was never actually applied

This was fixed since stable/wallaby in larger commit
Idf5c0041a0c6d3ed7d5d49fb68be856719916663

Change-Id: I652b994351595c0e28945ecf2f19a8d5892b99bc
Closes-Bug: #1937369
(cherry picked from commit 64be22d7780d6e898b7420ef46a529d9751d1cff)

Change-Id: I3c6b7a85f8cbf5a8379965c44be854ea3002123b
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-24 19:06:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix grep for /dev/disk/by-id to identify SCSI devices
    
    For VMs with hw_disk_bus=scsi and/or hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi
    the volume won't be identified, because for those VMs the result
    from `ls /dev/disk/by-id` will look like this:

commit_message:
Fix grep for /dev/disk/by-id to identify SCSI devices
    
    For VMs with hw_disk_bus=scsi and/or hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi
    the volume won't be identified, because for those VMs the result
    from `ls /dev/disk/by-id` will look like this:
    
    scsi-0QEMU_QEMU_HARDDISK_3c8f086d-e1f4-4ce1-a91a-c4a8d6d538bb
    
    This patch extends the current grep by allowing the full UUID of
    the volume to be matched as well.
    
    Change-Id: I3c6b7a85f8cbf5a8379965c44be854ea3002123b

Change-Id: Ic72948f50d9abb793e2a37255b2d7d175605aedf

Currently it is not possible to configure the staging directory
URI of the functional workers. We need to be able to do that in order
to enable the stage cleaning behavior. Right now, they're all sharing

"}]
commit_message:
Make functional tests set node_staging_uri

Currently it is not possible to configure the staging directory
URI of the functional workers. We need to be able to do that in order
to enable the stage cleaning behavior. Right now, they're all sharing
/tmp/staging, which will cause workers to conflict while running in
parallel. This causes them to use their private test directory,
which may also help some other spurious failures due to interaction.

Related-Bug: #1913625
Change-Id: Ic2ac2a528206c50c38e948a096daf9eb8e5eb715
(cherry picked from commit e9852fb6251c655f0e384c6b0b8677bd556f17a1)
(cherry picked from commit 8e216b4913e8b842cab983c100165949bed7def2)

The purpose of this patch is having the ability to have a general
set of tasks where the mgr (and global) config key are set.

commit_message:
Improve the config-key settings when Ceph is deployed

The purpose of this patch is having the ability to have a general
set of tasks where the mgr (and global) config key are set.
For development and debug purposes the tripleo_cephadm_debug
parameter is added, and can be used to have a more verbose output
from the orchestrator.

Change-Id: Ic2e54e537b50cb92b1650e78f1af61703e877763

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I4ec56c538282e2617ad7b069628165e8ec7a9c61

commit_message:
Deploy healthcheck middleware as app instead of filter

Using the healthcheck middleware as a filter is deprecated and
the middleware should be used as an application[1].
 [1] 6feaa13610c450c8486f969703768db5319b4846

This change updates definition and usage of the healthcheck middleware
accordingly to avoid the following deprecation warning.

DeprecationWarning: Using function/method 'Healthcheck.factory()' is
deprecated: The healthcheck middleware must now be configured as
an application, not as a filter.

Note that this change makes the apiversions endpoint available without
auth.

Closes-Bug: #1937901
Change-Id: I5d9a7cbc566e1f58afc03390806f76f9d973532b

commit_message:
Do not use mirror host for Ceph Luminous

Luminous is still used for Debian jobs, but mirror host doesn't provide
the required contents.

Backport note:
In Queens we use Ceph Luminous also for Ubuntu jobs.

Change-Id: I1120e881b0e7844978024ccab03b1f2eab97b098

commit_message:
Do not use mirror host for Ceph Luminous

Luminous is still used for Debian jobs, but mirror host doesn't provide
the required contents.

Change-Id: I1120e881b0e7844978024ccab03b1f2eab97b098

commit_message:
Add periodic task to remove postgres archived wal files

* Added a periodic task for postgresql datastore to clean up the
  archived WAL files.
* Added a check when creating incremental backups for postgresql.
* A new container image ``openstacktrove/db-backup-postgresql:1.1.2``
  is uploaded to docker hub.

Story: 2009066
Task: 42871
Change-Id: I235e2abf8c0405e143ded6fb48017d596b8b41a1

This release picks up new commits to masakari-monitors since

please respond with a +1 to let the release team know it is OK to
proceed.

If it is not wanted at this time, or if there are more changes that
would be good to get merged before doing a stable release, please

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 9.0.1..61b72e8

Change-Id: I8b3b26b6e1ea8b39b2666d6c7b33bce9cd2d49cb
'}]
commit_message:
Release masakari-monitors for stable/ussuri

This release picks up new commits to masakari-monitors since
the last release from stable/ussuri.

This is being proposed as a convenience to help make sure stable
changes are being released. If the team is good with this going out,
please respond with a +1 to let the release team know it is OK to
proceed.

If it is not wanted at this time, or if there are more changes that
would be good to get merged before doing a stable release, please
leave a -1 with a comment with what the team would prefer. We can
then either abandon this patch, or wait for an update with a new
commit hash to use instead.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 9.0.1..61b72e8
61b72e8 Drop lower-constraints
45b67c4 Fix the release jobs
72b74da Remove unnecessary continue statement

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I8b3b26b6e1ea8b39b2666d6c7b33bce9cd2d49cb

commit_message:
vncproxy: removal of tags and steps change from post_upgrade_tasks

Post upgrade tasks are limited to 4-1 steps, so these
tasks are not executed.

Deleting nova-consoleauth is failing with some of the CIs and this is
mostly a best-effort kind of task, so adding ignore_errors.

Also, replacing some yes/nos with boolean as it's best practice.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1921112
Change-Id: I0bc39170569c42a0be31233fd7ec068613547790
(cherry picked from commit 2001b48ca3430746f407b69d31d9e7e19303f9b8)

commit_message:
Build containers in gate  - to match check

tripleo-ci-centos-8-standalone-validation-libs
should have build_container_images: true
in gate if that setting is run in check.

This review adds a vars anchor to match
vars in check and gate.

Change-Id: Iec14a28a2a4d0000c7b4c573760eaeb603004cbd

commit_message:
vncproxy: removal of tags and steps change from post_upgrade_tasks

Post upgrade tasks are limited to 4-1 steps, so these
tasks are not executed.

Deleting nova-consoleauth is failing with some of the CIs and this is
mostly a best-effort kind of task, so adding ignore_errors.

Also, replacing some yes/nos with boolean as it's best practice.

NOTE(dvd): train-only modification: reverting back OS_CLOUD change as it
conflicts with the sourced stackrc credentials when running a scale down
as described in this LP#1931172

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1921112
Related-bug: #1931172
Change-Id: I0bc39170569c42a0be31233fd7ec068613547790
(cherry picked from commit 2001b48ca3430746f407b69d31d9e7e19303f9b8)

commit_message:
[stable only] Fix NeutronL3AgentAvailabilityZone parameter

The config setting had two checks in same item so the part about
NeutronL3AgentAvailabilityZone was never actually applied

This was fixed since stable/wallaby in larger commit
Idf5c0041a0c6d3ed7d5d49fb68be856719916663

Change-Id: I652b994351595c0e28945ecf2f19a8d5892b99bc
Closes-Bug: #1937369

commit_message:
Modify content providers in periodic line

This patch modifies content providers to their
specific release content provider for victoria
and ussuri template as its periodic line instead
of using master content provider.

Discussion reference :
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/796771/11#message-6a0f9c7b2ae25f00fee64041fcda6c0295266df8
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/796771/11#message-580db9cc7ad29d388872ac8f896bcad140647af8

[{'created': '2021-07-22 10:16:03.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.

defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.
By doing this the operator has the flexibility to use the network
defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)

[{'created': '2021-07-07 21:04:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add heat-api environment

Add an environment file that can be used to enable Heat API. While the
service is already enabled by default, there are other environments that
could be used to disable it (such as standalone-tripleo.yaml). Having
this environment makes the service easy to re-enable without having to
use a custom environment file.

Change-Id: Ib60631a1c17786fa6d4aa36da03b819846144806
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add heat-api environment

Add an environment file that can be used to enable Heat API. While the
service is already enabled by default, there are other environments that
could be used to disable it (such as standalone-tripleo.yaml). Having
this environment makes the service easy to re-enable without having to
use a custom environment file.

Change-Id: Ib60631a1c17786fa6d4aa36da03b819846144806
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2021-07-20 21:37:18.000000000', 'message': 'nova_virtlogd_wrapper: trap "created" containers

When an host shutdown isn't graceful, virtlogd container is orphaned but
in state "Created" (shown as "configured" in podman inspect). This
prevents the recreation of new virtlogd container by the wrapper.

Change-Id: If8356998818a8e0adc3c81f1fa10cb2f18a9a59f
'}]
commit_message:
nova_virtlogd_wrapper: trap "created" containers

When an host shutdown isn't graceful, virtlogd container is orphaned but
in state "Created" (shown as "configured" in podman inspect). This
prevents the recreation of new virtlogd container by the wrapper.

Change-Id: If8356998818a8e0adc3c81f1fa10cb2f18a9a59f

[{'created': '2021-07-23 14:30:27.000000000', 'message': "vncproxy: removal of tags and steps change from post_upgrade_tasks

Post upgrade tasks are limited to 4-1 steps, so these
tasks are not executed.

Deleting nova-consoleauth is failing with some of the CIs and this is
mostly a best-effort kind of task, so adding ignore_errors.

Also, replacing some yes/nos with boolean as it's best practice.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1921112
Change-Id: I0bc39170569c42a0be31233fd7ec068613547790
(cherry picked from commit 2001b48ca3430746f407b69d31d9e7e19303f9b8)
(cherry picked from commit 28c866c3e9acde7c34216e059d79ba96a43e6ddb)
"}]
commit_message:
vncproxy: removal of tags and steps change from post_upgrade_tasks

Post upgrade tasks are limited to 4-1 steps, so these
tasks are not executed.

Deleting nova-consoleauth is failing with some of the CIs and this is
mostly a best-effort kind of task, so adding ignore_errors.

Also, replacing some yes/nos with boolean as it's best practice.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1921112
Change-Id: I0bc39170569c42a0be31233fd7ec068613547790
(cherry picked from commit 2001b48ca3430746f407b69d31d9e7e19303f9b8)
(cherry picked from commit 28c866c3e9acde7c34216e059d79ba96a43e6ddb)

commit_message:
Add  tripleo-undercloud job

TripleO uses ironic + networking-baremetal in undercloud while it does
not use ironic in overcloud. This change adds tripleo-undercloud so
that code specific to networking-baremetal is tested.

commit_message:
Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.
By doing this the operator has the flexibility to use the network
defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)

commit_message:
Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.
By doing this the operator has the flexibility to use the network
defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)

commit_message:
vncproxy: removal of tags and steps change from post_upgrade_tasks

Post upgrade tasks are limited to 4-1 steps, so these
tasks are not executed.

Deleting nova-consoleauth is failing with some of the CIs and this is
mostly a best-effort kind of task, so adding ignore_errors.

Also, replacing some yes/nos with boolean as it's best practice.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1921112
Change-Id: I0bc39170569c42a0be31233fd7ec068613547790

commit_message:
Pass sync_backref=False to relationship call

Need to bump the lower-constraint of sqlalchemy
to a version where 'sync_backref' was introduced [1]

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/relationship_api.html#sqlalchemy.orm.relationship.params.sync_backref
Change-Id: I589281d8e77a160adcd48b8d3e4951441f843463
Closes-Bug: #1924806
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
s3api: Pass through 409s from SLO

It sure beats returning a 500, logging a traceback, and likely having
the client retry a bunch.

Change-Id: I0cedcf368d05583f2c2c9836ee9e5fa653866178

commit_message:
Replace deprecated scheduler filter module name

manila.scheduler.filter_scheduler.*Scheduler was deprecated long ago[1]
in favor of new manila.scheduler.drivers.filter.*Scheduler.

[1] 3ffb4979f328259793079a5ece6f3b79e23f5187

Change-Id: I40349cbe106f688a67043a73f8563f87f069831b

Test patch of this with all the cinder and glance dependencies seems happy now:

https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_74c/788963/2/check/glance-multistore-cinder-import/74c3d11/testr_results.html'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-06-04 06:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1 Review-Priority+1

(8 comments)

Some comments inline.

We cannot merge this until dependent cinderclient patch merges.

Also do we need to change any documentation for this;
https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/configuration/configuring.html#configuring-multiple-cinder-storage-backend

Please add release note as well.

Thank you Rajat!!!'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-06-04 11:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-06-04 11:17:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

(8 comments)

Thanks Abhishek for the review.

> Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1 Review-Priority+1
> 
> (8 comments)
> 
> Some comments inline.
> 
> We cannot merge this until dependent cinderclient patch merges.
> 
> Also do we need to change any documentation for this;
> https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/configuration/configuring.html#configuring-multiple-cinder-storage-backend
> 
I think this change doesn't affect multiple cinder stores since this is just adding the base framework for new attachment API. we do need documentation change but when we add the multiattach handling support with this patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance_store/+/786410
I will do documentation changes along with that one.

> Please add release note as well.
I'm not sure about releasenote here since releasenotes are targeted towards operators and end users which are not affected by this change. One change is the minimum cinder microversion required now is 3.54 which was introduced in rocky and we discussed in PTG that noone will be running a deployment with cinder-rocky and glance_store-xena
Let me know your thoughts about it.
> 
> Thank you Rajat!!!"}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-06-10 05:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+1

Thank you Rajat!!'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-07-06 05:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-07-23 15:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-07-23 16:23:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2021-07-23 16:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2

'}, {'created': '2021-03-29 17:47:35.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce new attachment API in glance cinder store

Cinder introduced new attachment API flow in microversion 3.27
which provides a clean interface to interact with cinder for
attachments and is also required for multiattach volume
support (Related future work).
Nova uses it since a long time and is proven to be stable,
this patch implements the same for glance.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-cinderclient/+/783628

Change-Id: I2758ed1d5b8e0981faa3eff6f83e1ce5975a01d2

multiattach volume support (Related future work).

this patch implements the same for glance.

commit_message:
Add cinder's new attachment support

Cinder introduced new attachment API flow in microversion 3.27
(also attachment_complete added in mv 3.44 and support for passing
mode added in mv 3.54) which provides a clean interface to
interact with cinder for attachments and is also required for
multiattach volume support (Related future work).
Nova uses it since a long time and is proven to be stable,
this patch implements the same for glance.
The create volume and delete volume calls are also moved to
cinder_utils file to use the generic exception handler
and keep similar code together for consistency.

Partially Implements: blueprint attachment-api-and-multiattach-support

Change-Id: I2758ed1d5b8e0981faa3eff6f83e1ce5975a01d2

commit_message:
Add support for RP re-parenting and orphaning

This patch adds the new microversion 1.37 in which changing the
parent_provider_uuid of a resource provider to any other provider
(except in the same subtree to avoid loops) or to null (un-parenting /
orphaning) is supported.

Story: 2008764
Task: 42131
Change-Id: I9d16ab7944d7e6ce725a892827b9508b7ba52d7c

commit_message:
Make explicit the network backend used in the CI jobs

All Neutron CI jobs (except for unit, functional and fullstack jobs),
have explicitly defined the network backend used:
- linuxbridge
- ovs
- ovn

That was discussed and approved during the Neutron CI meetings [1].

[1]https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/neutron_ci/2021/neutron_ci.2021-06-15-15.00.log.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797051
Change-Id: I4d18ef3e3adf24cf646e0546e7c38145f5a4aa92

commit_message:
Add amphora_id in store params for failover_amphora

Several tasks require amphora_id parameter to be passed in
get_amphora_for_lb_failover_subflow.
Execution passed results in error:

taskflow.exceptions.NotFound: Mapped argument 'amphora_id' <=
'amphora_id' was not produced by any accessible provider
(1 possible providers were scanned).

Also fix getting ID parameter from amphora dict in
AmphoraIndexListenersReload and add missing retries for create_*
resources in v2 worker.

Change-Id: I5ed6288b2776bd7f1c9b67e9cfd9a8f05b1196be
(cherry picked from commit 1a154839c2dfb5a9c89963b27a96f0adef1038ee)
(cherry picked from commit ee7b262199840bca7f08a111ea535392396bb416)

commit_message:
Deprecate os-panko role

Since upstream Panko project has retired, we deprecating role for it.

Since we might want to get some patches in for stable branches, we're
deprecating role instead of retiring it.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/project-config/+/799808
Change-Id: Idefe36d87dcd573884158b0885df163f9dc18334

commit_message:
Retire django-openstack-auth

``django_openstack_auth`` code was merged into the main horizon
repository during the queens release. This repo is already
deprecated and now we can retire it. This patch removes all
references of ``django_openstack_auth`` as mentioned in [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/repository.html#retiring-a-repository

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/project-config/+/800532
Change-Id: Iff2209ced9b75884470c72c580ed0ea8135ec188

subject: Convert deprecation fields warnings to error
messages:
[{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-22 23:43:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 00:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 00:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

cross-nova-tox-functional fail for the placement fixes are not yet released in pypi from where nova test pick placement. We need to wait for placement new version to be released.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 01:28:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck keystone error fixed in depends-on'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-07-23 14:16:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm not overly fond of this idea. The warnings infrastructure provides a way to tweak this stuff. Projects like nova enable warnings in tests only to (in theory) catch things as they arise but crucially deprecation warnings are not supposed to be raised in production by default. If they're being enabled then something is causing that default to change. That's the real bug, IMO.

If we do this, we're going to need a new major version bump as it's a breaking change. However, I think it would be much wiser to figure out why users are seeing these in production so we can address the root cause. Until we figure that out, users can pass the '-W ignore::DeprecationWarning' flag to their 'python3' executable or set the 'PYTHONWARNINGS=ignore::DeprecationWarning' environment option."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 17:54:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> I'm not overly fond of this idea. The warnings infrastructure provides a way to tweak this stuff. Projects like nova enable warnings in tests only to (in theory) catch things as they arise but crucially deprecation warnings are not supposed to be raised in production by default. If they're being enabled then something is causing that default to change. That's the real bug, IMO.
> 
> If we do this, we're going to need a new major version bump as it's a breaking change. However, I think it would be much wiser to figure out why users are seeing these in production so we can address the root cause. Until we figure that out, users can pass the '-W ignore::DeprecationWarning' flag to their 'python3' executable or set the 'PYTHONWARNINGS=ignore::DeprecationWarning' environment option.

We have two issues with warnings (as discussed in http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-July/023646.html)

1. our CI/CD logging infra crash on so many warnings via tests. A few project has disabled these warning explicitly but not all do by default and that blow out the logs. Ironic was one example when we started seeing ~1k warnings from tests. 

2. I might be missing something but how we are controlling that warnings should not be seen in operation logs? I think they are logged in operation logs also unless explicitly disabled ?

But with both cases, I think fixing and disabling/converting then to error is our main goal of warnings. these warnings are fixed in existing projects and to avoid new usage of Rule objects who produce warnings we should convert them to error asap(right after 1 cycle).

Hope this clarify the situation of warnings becoming so much problem with our current logging infra where we are trying to reduce the logs worker etc."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 17:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-23 18:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

with the placement is not released with the fix of moving to new style we have to wait until next cycle.'}]

commit_message:
Convert deprecation fields warnings to error

We have merged all the current usage of the old
way (except depends-on) to fix the deprecation rule
warngings

- https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22fix-oslo-policy-warnings%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)

These warnings are creating lot of issue for logging infra
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-July/023646.html

and one way to avoid such lot of warnings in future is to fix the current usage
(at least in OpenStack) and convert them to error.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/799423

Change-Id: Ib38557affb1a178cb1755cfbc61441ed46c1294f

commit_message:
Retire django-openstack-auth

This patch is a follow-up patch for
Ifa691c2d2e7ac8bb502c8fae7dbdcc89fa4ef825 which removes
"django_openstack_auth" project template reference from ``zuul.d/projects.yaml``.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/django_openstack_auth/+/800133

Change-Id: Iaab900d48aaa2f21abb048403138d03628ad7617

Fix an error in the document

file. This patch changes "default" to "DEFAULT" so

become effective.

commit_message:
Remove testr

* Remove .testr.conf as it's not used anywhere and update .gitignore
  lower-constraints.txt and test-requirements.txt accordingly
* Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

subject: Remove noop jobs for deprecated os-panko
messages:
[{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-07 12:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-07-15 16:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

question: Do we need this now?
We usually keep noop-job for the master branch until the repo is retired completely.
noop-job needs to be kept as we need at least one job in the check and gate queues to get results from the CI (in the master branch). If no further maintenance change happens in the master branch, it would be okay.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-16 06:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> question: Do we need this now?
> We usually keep noop-job for the master branch until the repo is retired completely.
> noop-job needs to be kept as we need at least one job in the check and gate queues to get results from the CI (in the master branch). If no further maintenance change happens in the master branch, it would be okay.

We dropped all content from master branch, which is part of the deprecation process afaik. messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-07-23 11:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2021-07-23 11:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\ngreat, thks'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2021-07-23 13:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-23 11:51:42.000000000', 'message': 'tests: Handle removal of block-storage v2 API

Cinder recently removed their v2 API [1] which is causing the functional
tests to fail. Improve our 'is_service_enabled' test helper to use the
'versions show' command, which queries the service catalog and can give
us information about the service version as well as answer the more
general "is this service available" question. We also resolve a
long-standing TODO in the process.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/792299

Change-Id: I381069357aa008344e15327adf3a863c0c2e1f04
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
tests: Handle removal of block-storage v2 API

Cinder recently removed their v2 API [1] which is causing the functional
tests to fail. Improve our 'is_service_enabled' test helper to use the
'versions show' command, which queries the service catalog and can give
us information about the service version as well as answer the more
general "is this service available" question. We also resolve a
long-standing TODO in the process.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/792299

Change-Id: I381069357aa008344e15327adf3a863c0c2e1f04
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-23 08:01:37.000000000', 'message': 'Implement namespace creation method

Since [1], Pyroute forks the namespace creation to avoid calling
destructive routine "libc.unshare(CLONE_NEWNET)" from the main
process. This implementation uses sockets between both processes
to return any error feedback sent from the child process.

This patch implements the same fork without any communication. If
the child process raises an exception other than "OSError(EEXIST)",
the child process returns 1 that is read by the the main process,
that raises a "RuntimeError" exception.

Related-Bug: #1917487

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/81db2c98a1dda1c575ae087519cb08aa6ffdb39e

Change-Id: I0294586335a71d0757803843f675124bfb450967
(cherry picked from commit eb567478516897fadac1b7d205bef5c86284eace)
'}]
commit_message:
Implement namespace creation method

Since [1], Pyroute forks the namespace creation to avoid calling
destructive routine "libc.unshare(CLONE_NEWNET)" from the main
process. This implementation uses sockets between both processes
to return any error feedback sent from the child process.

This patch implements the same fork without any communication. If
the child process raises an exception other than "OSError(EEXIST)",
the child process returns 1 that is read by the the main process,
that raises a "RuntimeError" exception.

Related-Bug: #1917487

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/81db2c98a1dda1c575ae087519cb08aa6ffdb39e

Change-Id: I0294586335a71d0757803843f675124bfb450967
(cherry picked from commit eb567478516897fadac1b7d205bef5c86284eace)

subject: Setup dates for Yoga combined election
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2033, 'name': 'Belmiro Moreira', 'email': 'moreira.belmiro.email.lists@gmail.com', 'username': 'moreira-belmiro-email-lists'}, {'_account_id': 7198, 'name': 'Jay Bryant', 'email': 'jungleboyj@electronicjungle.net', 'username': 'jsbryant'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 14482, 'name': 'Ian Y. Choi', 'email': 'ianyrchoi@gmail.com', 'username': 'ianychoi'}, {'_account_id': 15993, 'name': 'Amy Marrich', 'display_name': 'Amy Marrich (spotz)', 'email': 'amy@demarco.com', 'username': 'amarrich'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 32070, 'name': 'Helena Spease', 'email': 'helena@openstack.org', 'username': 'hspease'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-20 22:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-20 23:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2021-07-20 23:31:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

So I have no "skin in this game" so I should leave it be.  To me bottom line is that english is *NOT* a precise language and the charter is open to interpretation by the officials.  The dates Kendall selected match the interpretation of the charter that's been used in the past, the dates Ghanshyam selects match his.

The Election takes 3 weeks (nominations. campaigning and voting), the charter specifies a 3 week window, so another interpretation is that the charter prescribes *exactly* when the election must be held[1] but almost certainly at some stage that will not be possible.  The charter and release calendar don't specify a timezone so ... when exactly does R-6 begin?   We default to UTC but that's another interpretation.

Who's to say which is correct or incorrect.

Really does it matter?  Will there be a catastrophe if we interpret the charter differently?  Will the election outcome be radically different if it finishes on Aug-24 or Sep-10? Will there be grounds to nulify/overturn the election?

So here's my vote both this change and 798719 match *an* interpretation of the charter, they both get a +1.

[1] This change has the *election* starting in R-7'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2021-07-20 23:36:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-21 14:31:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
> 
> So I have no "skin in this game" so I should leave it be.  To me bottom line is that english is *NOT* a precise language and the charter is open to interpretation by the officials.  The dates Kendall selected match the interpretation of the charter that's been used in the past, the dates Ghanshyam selects match his.
> 
> The Election takes 3 weeks (nominations. campaigning and voting), the charter specifies a 3 week window, so another interpretation is that the charter prescribes *exactly* when the election must be held[1] but almost certainly at some stage that will not be possible.  The charter and release calendar don't specify a timezone so ... when exactly does R-6 begin?   We default to UTC but that's another interpretation.
> 
> Who's to say which is correct or incorrect.
> 
> Really does it matter?  Will there be a catastrophe if we interpret the charter differently?  Will the election outcome be radically different if it finishes on Aug-24 or Sep-10? Will there be grounds to nulify/overturn the election?
> 
> So here's my vote both this change and 798719 match *an* interpretation of the charter, they both get a +1.
> 
> [1] This change has the *election* starting in R-7

I think, the date selected in 798719 patch is via current script setup-election-config which has the old dates as per the Summit things. ( "The election is held no later than 6 weeks prior to each OpenStack Summit (on or before 'S-6' week)") 

That is fixed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/election/+/801539/1 and if you generate the dates on top of that fix then it would match charter also.

Election starting in R-7 (as proposed in 798719) cannot be as per charter which clearly says election to be held between R-6 to R4 week.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-07-21 14:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-21 15:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-21 15:20:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2021-07-21 15:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2021-07-21 15:53:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I think this looks right to me.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-21 17:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2021-07-22 15:09:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 32070, 'date': '2021-07-23 12:42:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2021-07-23 16:45:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Setup dates for Yoga combined election

Yoga cycle is going to have combined election.

As per the TC charter:
- TC election needs to be held in between of R6 to R4 week of Xena release
- PTL election needs to be held on or before R3 week.

Ref: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/charter.html

Release dates:
If we combine both election schedule as per TC charter it comes as:
between R6 to R4 week:
R-6: Aug 23
R-4: Sep 10

Ref: https://releases.openstack.org/xena/schedule.html

Change-Id: Ic58a85b83f8178086a3f1721009ddd4af3594e50

commit_message:
Add 'combined' election support in setup-election-config

setup-election-config script is used to generate the
election dates. As we started doing the combined election
of PTL and TC, we need to add that type of election support
in this tool which will help to generate dates for any
type of election.

Below the is generated data will looks like:

release: yoga
election_type: combined
tag: oct-2021-elections
tc_seats: 4
timeframe:
  name: Wallaby-Xena
  start: 2020-09-25T00:00
  end: 2021-08-24T00:00
  email_deadline: 2021-08-24T00:00
timeline:
- name: TC & PTL Nominations
  start: 2021-08-17T23:45
  end: 2021-08-24T23:45
- name: TC Campaigning
  start: 2021-08-24T23:45
  end: 2021-08-31T23:45
- name: TC & PTL Election
  start: 2021-08-31T23:45
  end: 2021-09-07T23:45

Change-Id: Ib97f7ba794078ed78c9241dce7d40b3fc3519948

commit_message:
Implement project personas for metadef property and tags APIs

This commit updates the policies for metadef property and
metadef tags to use default roles available from keystone.

Implements: blueprint secure-rbac
Change-Id: Iaeda207568440a1ce2dad8934243f2e1a107b36b

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-23 08:01:56.000000000', 'message': 'Implement namespace creation method

Since [1], Pyroute forks the namespace creation to avoid calling
destructive routine "libc.unshare(CLONE_NEWNET)" from the main
process. This implementation uses sockets between both processes
to return any error feedback sent from the child process.

This patch implements the same fork without any communication. If
the child process raises an exception other than "OSError(EEXIST)",
the child process returns 1 that is read by the the main process,
that raises a "RuntimeError" exception.

Related-Bug: #1917487

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/81db2c98a1dda1c575ae087519cb08aa6ffdb39e

Change-Id: I0294586335a71d0757803843f675124bfb450967
(cherry picked from commit eb567478516897fadac1b7d205bef5c86284eace)
'}]
commit_message:
Implement namespace creation method

Since [1], Pyroute forks the namespace creation to avoid calling
destructive routine "libc.unshare(CLONE_NEWNET)" from the main
process. This implementation uses sockets between both processes
to return any error feedback sent from the child process.

This patch implements the same fork without any communication. If
the child process raises an exception other than "OSError(EEXIST)",
the child process returns 1 that is read by the the main process,
that raises a "RuntimeError" exception.

Related-Bug: #1917487

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/81db2c98a1dda1c575ae087519cb08aa6ffdb39e

Change-Id: I0294586335a71d0757803843f675124bfb450967
(cherry picked from commit eb567478516897fadac1b7d205bef5c86284eace)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-20 14:51:22.000000000', 'message': 'Support the new port resource_request format

By adding a new NeutronFixture derivative we can simulate that Neutron
returns the new nested structure in the resource_request attribute of
the port.

Also this adds two test class derivatives to run the existing resource
request tests with the new fixture and therefore with the new
resource_request format.

NOTE: This is a PoC showing how can we potentially support both the old
and the new formats. This change only adds as little as possible to make
the existing functional tests passing with the new format. It adds a
bunch of TODOs to remove the assumption that a port only has a single
request group as with the new request format we allow more request
groups per port in neutron.

TODO:
* make a decision if we need to support both format in Xena. If only the
  new format is needed then this patch can be simplified a lot.

blueprint: qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet-rate
Change-Id: I1a295861d63779cd97a1dce4f9b5cfd8c5fd2e72

commit_message:
Support the new port resource_request format

This patch adds two test class derivatives to run the existing
resource request tests with the new Neutron fixture and therefore
with the new resource_request format.

NOTE: This change only adds as little as possible to make
the existing functional tests passing with the new format. It adds a
bunch of TODOs to remove the assumption that a port only has a single
request group as with the new request format we allow more request
groups per port in neutron.

TODO:
* unit test coverage
* maybe split it up to smaller pieces

blueprint: qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet-rate
Change-Id: I1a295861d63779cd97a1dce4f9b5cfd8c5fd2e72

commit_message:
Add Health Monitor support

TCP and UDP Connect health monitors are now supported by the
provider driver, when the underlying OVN version supports
them.

The health monitor uses the OVN distributed DHCP port as the
source IP for messages, one must exist or the create or update
operation will fail. The list of member ports to monitor is
updated whenever one is created or deleted.

Added support for SBDB notifications for Service Monitor
events generated when the OVN health monitor code detects
issues with connectivity. This will trigger updates to the
Octavia objects as members go on/offline so that the Octavia
API reflects the current running state of the load balancer.

Added a lot of new unit and functional tests to cover all the
new code, and enabled the tempest health monitor feature so
those tests are run as well.

Change-Id: I776a7a6b036ad72ce7eaa1ab39f448b344974be6

This adds a middleware to neutron as an alternative to noauth in
standalone environments.

This middleware uses a password file which supports the Apache htpasswd
syntax. This file is read for every request, so no service restart is
required when changes are made.

The only password digest supported is bcrypt, and the ``bcrypt``
python library is used for password checks since it supports ``$2y$``
prefixed bcrypt passwords as generated by the Apache htpasswd utility.

commit_message:
Add basic http authentication support for neutron

This adds a middleware to neutron as an alternative to noauth in
standalone environments.

This middleware uses a password file which supports the Apache htpasswd
syntax. This file is read for every request, so no service restart is
required when changes are made.

The only password digest supported is bcrypt, and the ``bcrypt``
python library is used for password checks since it supports ``$2y$``
prefixed bcrypt passwords as generated by the Apache htpasswd utility.

Closes-Bug: #1935847
Change-Id: I3fdcd9fe6a9c4b025f3c6789d57c4377839e72c6
